Provision.Text: Her Excellency the Governor General in Council, on the recommendation of the Minister of Transport, pursuant to section 5 of the Marine Transportation Security Acta, hereby makes the annexed Marine Transportation Security Regulations.

Subsection.Text: The following definitions apply in these Regulations.

Definition.Text: Act means the Marine Transportation Security Act. (Loi)
approved training course means a course that has been approved under section 803 and that is given by a recognized institution. (cours de formation approuvé)
CDC facility means a marine facility where any of the following operations are carried out:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the manufacture or storage of certain dangerous cargoes intended to be transferred to a vessel to which Part 2 applies;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the storage of certain dangerous cargoes transferred from a vessel to which Part 2 applies; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the transfer of certain dangerous cargoes to or from a vessel to which Part 2 applies. (installation CCD)

Definition.Text: CDC residue means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of CDCs having the UN number UN1942, UN2067, UN2426 or UN3375 that are carried in a large means of containment and are intended for sale, residue that remains on board a vessel after the CDCs are unloaded, that does not exceed 450 kg in total quantity, and each of whose accumulations has a volume that does not exceed 0.05 m3; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of liquids and liquefied gases that are carried in a large means of containment, residue that remains in the cargo unloading system after the liquids and liquefied gases are unloaded and that is not accessible using normal transfer procedures, with the exception of the residue of liquefied gases having the UN number UN1005, UN1017, UN1035, UN1040, UN1062, UN1079, UN1086 or UN1971. (résidu de CCD)

Definition.Text: certain dangerous cargoesorCDCs means the dangerous goods that are set out in Schedule 4 and that are listed in Schedule 1 to the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Regulations or in Part 3 of the IMDG Code. (certaines cargaisons dangereusesouCCD)
container means a structure for transporting commodities on trucks, railcars or vessels that meets the requirements set out in the Safe Containers Convention Act. (conteneur)
container terminal means any marine facility that accepts containers for transport. (terminal pour conteneurs)
contracting government means the government of a state that is a signatory to SOLAS. (gouvernement contractant)
cruise ship means a vessel to which Part 2 applies and that has sleeping facilities for over 100 persons who are not crew members, but does not include a ferry. (navire de croisière)
cruise ship terminal means a marine facility that interfaces with cruise ships. (terminal pour navires de croisière)
dangerous goods means dangerous goods as defined in section 2 of the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992. (marchandises dangereuses)
declaration of security means an agreement between a vessel and a marine facility or another vessel that is required by section 228 or 315. (déclaration de sûreté)
ferry means a vessel that is used exclusively for the carriage of passengers, vehicles, or passengers in vehicles and that operates on a fixed schedule between two or more points. (traversier)
ferry facility means a marine facility that interfaces with ferries to which Part 2 applies. (installation pour traversiers)
fishing vessel has the meaning assigned by subsection 1(1) of the Marine Personnel Regulations. (bâtiment de pêche)
government vessel means a vessel, other than one operated for a commercial purpose,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that is owned by and is in the service of Her Majesty in right of Canada or that is in the exclusive possession of Her Majesty in that right; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that is owned by and is in the service of a foreign government or that is in the exclusive possession of a foreign government. (bâtiment d’État)

Definition.Text: IMDG Code means the International Maritime Dangerous Goods Code, published by the International Maritime Organization, as amended from time to time. (Code IMDG)

interface means the interaction that occurs between a vessel and a marine facility, or between a vessel and another vessel, throughout the time that the vessel is alongside the marine facility or throughout the vessel-to-vessel activity, and includes the activities affected by the movement of persons and their goods, by the movement of cargo or by the provision of services to and from the vessel. (interface)
international voyage means a voyage

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: undertaken between a marine facility in Canada and a place outside Canada, or between places outside Canada, by a vessel that is entitled to fly the Canadian flag; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: undertaken in Canadian waters by a vessel that is entitled to fly the flag of a foreign state. (voyage international)

Definition.Text: ISPS Code means the International Ship and Port Facility Security Code, as incorporated into SOLAS. (Code ISPS)
key means a device, including a card, that is designed to allow entry to a restricted area and is issued to an individual by an operator of a marine facility or vessel or port administration. (clé)
large means of containment has the meaning assigned by section 1.4 of the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Regulations. (grand contenant)
marine security document means any certificate, document or letter issued by the Minister under these Regulations. (document de sûreté maritime)
MARSEC level means the level of security requirements that is set by the Minister to reflect the threat environment for vessels, marine facilities and ports. (niveau MARSEC)
MARSEC level 1 means the level for which minimum security requirements are required to be implemented in accordance with the approved security plan or approved security procedures. (niveau MARSEC 1)

MARSEC level 2 means the level for which additional security requirements are required to be implemented as a result of heightened risk in accordance with the approved security plan or approved security procedures. (niveau MARSEC 2)

MARSEC level 3 means the level for which additional security requirements are required to be implemented as a result of a security threat that is probable or imminent, whether or not the specific target is identified, in accordance with the approved security plan or approved security procedures. (niveau MARSEC 3)
non-SOLAS ship means a vessel that is not a SOLAS ship, that is engaged on an international voyage, and that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is more than 100 gross tonnage but is not a towing vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is carrying more than 12 passengers; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is a towing vessel engaged in towing astern or alongside, or pushing ahead, a barge that is carrying certain dangerous cargoes. (navire non ressortissant à SOLAS)

Definition.Text: occasional-use marine facility means a marine facility that, in a calendar year, has 10 or fewer interfaces with vessels to which Part 2 applies. (installation maritime à usage occasionnel)
operator means, in respect of a vessel,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the actual owner, if the vessel is not registered, or the registered owner, if the vessel is registered;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a person having a beneficial interest in the vessel, including an interest arising under contract and any other equitable interest, other than an interest by way of a mortgage;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a lessee or charterer of the vessel who is responsible for its navigation; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the vessel is a barge referred to in paragraph (c) of the definition non-SOLAS ship, the master or any other person who has command or charge of the vessel that is towing or pushing the barge. (exploitant)

Definition.Text: passenger has the meaning assigned by section 2 of the Canada Shipping Act, 2001. (passager)
passenger facility means a marine facility that interfaces with passenger vessels to which Part 2 applies. (installation pour passagers)
pleasure craft has the meaning assigned by section 2 of the Canada Shipping Act, 2001. (embarcation de plaisance)
port means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a port as defined in section 5 of the Canada Marine Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a public port designated under regulations made under section 65 of the Canada Marine Act in which a marine facility that interfaces with a vessel to which Part 2 applies is situated; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a group of marine facilities, in close proximity to each other, whose operators agree with each other to be subject to sections 362 to 375. (port)

Definition.Text: port administration means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the operator of a marine facility that is a port authority incorporated under section 8 of the Canada Marine Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an employee of the Department of Transport who is designated by the Minister as the security officer for a port as defined in paragraph (c) of the definition port; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the absence of a port administration described in paragraph (a) or (b), the operator of a marine facility who is identified in an agreement referred to in paragraph (c) of the definition port to act as the port administration of the port. (organisme portuaire)

Definition.Text: recognized institution means a training institution that is designated as a recognized institution by the Minister under section 803.1 and that administers, in accordance with the requirements and established practices of the domestic and international marine industry, approved training courses for the purpose of providing the training necessary to obtain a certificate of proficiency issued under Part 8. (établissement reconnu)

restricted area pass means a document issued by an operator of a marine facility or vessel or port administration that entitles the holder, during a specified period, to have access to specific restricted areas in vessels, marine facilities or ports. (laissez-passer de zone réglementée)

security breach means a violation of these Regulations, of a security measure formulated under subsection 7(1) of the Act, of a security rule formulated under subsection 10(2) or (3) of the Act, or of a security procedure set out in an approved security plan or approved under subsection 360(1), that does not result in a security incident. (infraction à la sûreté)
security incident means an event during which the security of a vessel, marine facility or port is compromised. (incident de sûreté)
security threat means any suspicious act or circumstance that could compromise the security of a vessel, marine facility, port or interface. (menace contre la sûreté)
SOLAS means the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea, 1974, as amended from time to time. (SOLAS)
SOLAS ship means a vessel that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is 500 gross tonnage or more or is carrying more than 12 passengers; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is engaged on an international voyage other than a voyage solely on the Great Lakes and the St. Lawrence River as far seaward as a straight line drawn from Cap-des-Rosiers to West Point, Anticosti Island, and from Anticosti Island to the north shore of the St. Lawrence River along the meridian of longitude 63° W. (navire ressortissant à SOLAS)

Definition.Text: STCW Code means the Seafarers’ Training, Certification and Watchkeeping Code, published by the International Maritime Organization, as amended from time to time. (Code STCW)

STCW Convention means the International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping for Seafarers, published by the International Maritime Organization, as amended from time to time. (Convention STCW)
towing vessel means a vessel that tows another vessel astern or alongside or that pushes another vessel ahead. (bâtiment remorqueur)
transportation security clearance means a security clearance granted by the Minister under section 509. (habilitation de sécurité en matière de transport)

vessel personnel without security responsibilities means crew members, other than the vessel security officer or the company security officer, who do not have security responsibilities under the vessel’s security plan. (personnel du bâtiment n’ayant pas des responsabilités en matière de sûreté)

vessel personnel with security responsibilities means crew members, other than the vessel security officer or the company security officer, who have security responsibilities under the vessel’s security plan. (personnel du bâtiment ayant des responsabilités en matière de sûreté)

Subsection.Text: For the purpose of interpreting the ISPS Code, company shall be read to mean operator.
For the purposes of the definition international voyage in subsection (1), a vessel that is entitled to fly the Canadian flag

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: begins its international voyage at the beginning of its last interface with a marine facility in Canada before it engages on the voyage; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ends its international voyage at the end of its first interface with a marine facility in Canada when it returns from the voyage.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of the definition certain dangerous cargoesorCDCs in subsection (1), a reference to a UN number in Schedule 4 is a reference to the goods that are listed in Schedule 1 to the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Regulations or in Part 3 of the IMDG Code.

Section.Text: For greater certainty, nothing in these Regulations derogates from any right otherwise provided to a representative of seafarers’ welfare and labour organizations to access a vessel or a marine facility, unless there is an immediate threat to the safety and security of the vessel or marine facility.

Heading.TitleText: MARSEC Level, Official Languages and Prescribed Grounds

Section.Text: The operator of a vessel to which Part 2 applies and the operator of a marine facility or a port administration to which Part 3 applies shall maintain MARSEC level 1 at all times unless a higher MARSEC level is required by the Minister.

The operator of a vessel that is entitled to fly the Canadian flag and to which Part 2 applies, and the operator of a marine facility to which Part 3 applies, other than the operator of a marine facility that is referred to in paragraph (a) of the definition port administration in subsection 1(1) or the security officer referred to in paragraph (b) of that definition, shall ensure that, where there is a significant demand from at least 5 per cent of the travelling public for services in either official language within the meaning of the Official Languages (Communications with and Services to the Public) Regulations,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: authorized screening is carried out by means that effectively enable communication with members of the public in the official language of their choice; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: printed or pre-recorded material is provided in both official languages if the material is used in respect of authorized screening.

Section.Text: For the purposes of subsection 47(1) of the Act, the prescribed grounds are those that exist when a decision is made in consideration of the possibility of an immediate risk to the security of marine transportation.

Heading.TitleText: Suspension or Cancellation of Marine Security Documents

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall suspend or cancel a marine security document issued to the operator of a vessel or marine facility, or to a port administration, if the Minister has reasonable grounds to believe that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the document was obtained by any fraudulent or improper means or by a misrepresentation of any material fact;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the document was altered, rendered illegible or lost;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the operator or port administration

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is not in compliance with its approved security plan or, in the case of an occasional-use marine facility, its security procedures approved under subsection 360(1), or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: conducts its activities in a way that constitutes, or is likely to constitute, a threat to marine transportation security; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the requirements for issuance of the document are no longer met.

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall notify the operator or the port administration of the suspension or cancellation by notice served in accordance with section 701. The notice shall include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the grounds for the suspension or cancellation and the date on which the suspension or cancellation takes effect; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the address at which, and the date — being 30 days after the day on which the notice is served — on or before which, the operator or port administration may file a request to the Tribunal for a review of the suspension or cancellation.

Subsection.Text: The suspension or cancellation takes effect

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: no later than 30 days after the day on which the notice is served, if the ground for the suspension or cancellation is one of the grounds set out in paragraph (1)(a) or (b), subparagraph (1)(c)(i) or paragraph (1)(d); or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at the time the notice is served, if the ground for the suspension or cancellation is the ground set out in subparagraph (1)(c)(ii).

Subsection.Text: If a marine security document is suspended or cancelled, the operator or port administration to which it was issued shall return it immediately to the Minister.

Section.Text: The Tribunal has jurisdiction in respect of reviews and appeals under sections 16 to 19.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a vessel or marine facility, or a port administration, may file with the Tribunal a written request for a review of a suspension or cancellation referred to in subsection 14(1) on or before the date specified in the notice of suspension or cancellation or within any further time that the Tribunal allows on application.
A request for a review does not operate as a stay of the suspension or cancellation.

On receipt of a request filed under section 16, the Tribunal shall appoint a time and place for the review and shall notify in writing the Minister and the operator of the vessel or marine facility, or the port administration, of the time and place.
The assigned member of the Tribunal shall confirm the suspension or cancellation or refer the matter back to the Minister for reconsideration.

Within 30 days after the day on which a determination is made under subsection 17(2), the operator of the vessel or marine facility, or the port administration, may appeal the determination to the Tribunal.
A party who does not appear at a review hearing is not entitled to appeal a determination unless they establish that there was sufficient reason to justify their absence.
The appeal panel of the Tribunal assigned to hear the appeal shall dismiss it or refer the matter back to the Minister for reconsideration.

Section.Text: If a matter is referred back to the Minister for reconsideration under subsection 17(2) or 18(3), the suspension or cancellation remains in effect until the reconsideration is concluded. However, the member who made the determination or the appeal panel, after considering any representations made by the parties, may grant a stay of the suspension or cancellation until the reconsideration is concluded if the member or panel determines that granting a stay would not constitute a threat to marine transportation security.

Subsection.Text: This Part applies to vessels in Canada, and Canadian ships outside Canada, that are SOLAS ships or non-SOLAS ships.
This Part does not apply to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a pleasure craft, a fishing vessel, a vessel that is owned or operated by a government and used only on government non-commercial service, a vessel without a crew that is in dry dock, dismantled or laid-up, or a vessel that is subject to a security arrangement concluded between the Government of Canada and a contracting government in application of Regulation 11 of Chapter XI-2 of SOLAS; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a vessel that is entitled to fly the Canadian flag and that is engaged on a voyage between marine facilities in Canada, except when the vessel has an interface with a SOLAS ship or non-SOLAS ship that is entitled to fly the flag of a foreign state that is not subject to a security arrangement referred to in paragraph (a).

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsections 211(6) and 213(2), Administration means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of a SOLAS ship that is entitled to fly the Canadian flag, the Minister; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of a SOLAS ship that is entitled to fly the flag of a foreign state, the contracting government of that state.

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall issue an International Ship Security Certificate, in English or French, in respect of a Canadian ship that is a SOLAS ship if the requirements of paragraph 204(1)(b) and sections 205, 207 to 218, 220, 222 to 225 and 260 are met.

The Minister shall issue a Canadian Vessel Security Certificate, in English or French, in respect of a vessel that is entitled to fly the Canadian flag and is a non-SOLAS ship if the requirements of paragraph 204(1)(b) and sections 205, 207 to 218, 220 and 260 are met.

The Minister shall issue an interim International Ship Security Certificate or Canadian Vessel Security Certificate, as the case may be, in English or French, if the vessel security plan is approved but an inspection under section 23 of the Act has not yet been carried out to ensure compliance with the requirements referred to in subsection (1) or (2), as the case may be.
A certificate issued under subsection (1) or (2) is valid while the vessel security plan is valid.

An interim certificate issued under subsection (3) is valid until the expiry of six months after the day on which it is issued or until a certificate is issued under subsection (1) or (2), whichever comes first.
The operator of a SOLAS ship that is entitled to fly the Canadian flag shall ensure that the requirements of sections 204 to 268 are met.
The operator of a non-SOLAS ship that is entitled to fly the Canadian flag shall ensure that the requirements of sections 204 to 221 and 228 to 268 are met.
The operator of a SOLAS ship that is entitled to fly the flag of a foreign state shall ensure that the requirements of the following are met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: section 204, paragraph 205(1)(e), subparagraph 205(1)(f)(ii), paragraphs 205(1)(h) and (i), subsections 206(1) to (4), paragraph 206(5)(b), subsection 211(1), paragraphs 211(3)(b), 212(h) to (h.2) and 213(1)(b), subsection 213(2), paragraph 214(1)(b) and sections 219, 221, 228 and 260 to 268; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: sections 7 and 9 to 13, other than sections 7.8, 7.9 and 9.2, of Part A of the ISPS Code.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a non-SOLAS ship that is entitled to fly the flag of a foreign state shall ensure that the requirements of the following are met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: section 204, paragraph 205(1)(e), section 206, subsections 211(1) and (2), 213(3) and 214(2) and sections 219, 221, 228 and 260 to 268; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: sections 7 and 9 to 13, other than sections 7.8, 7.9, 9.2 and 9.4.16, of Part A of the ISPS Code.

Subsection.Text: In the event of any conflict between the requirements of the ISPS Code and the provisions of these Regulations, the provisions of these Regulations prevail to the extent of the conflict.

Heading.TitleText: Documents to Be Carried on Board

Subsection.Text: Every vessel shall carry on board

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the original of the certificate described in subsection (2);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a vessel security plan approved

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of a vessel entitled to fly the Canadian flag, by the Minister, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of a vessel entitled to fly the flag of a foreign state, by a contracting government or by a security organization referred to in section 9.2 of Part A of the ISPS Code;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a continuous synopsis record issued by a contracting government, if the vessel is a SOLAS ship;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a record of the last 10 calls at marine facilities;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the last 10 declarations of security; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: if the vessel is a SOLAS ship, the original of every certificate of proficiency required by this Part for the vessel security officer and for vessel personnel with or without security responsibilities.

Subsection.Text: The certificate referred to in paragraph (1)(a) is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a SOLAS ship that is entitled to fly the Canadian flag, a certificate issued under subsection 202(1) or (3);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a non-SOLAS ship that is entitled to fly the Canadian flag, a certificate issued under subsection 202(2) or (3);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a SOLAS ship that is entitled to fly the flag of a foreign state, an international ship security certificate, or an interim international ship security certificate, issued by the contracting government of that state; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a non-SOLAS ship that is entitled to fly the flag of a foreign state, a ship security compliance document, or an interim ship security compliance document, issued or approved by the contracting government of that state.

Subsection.Text: The vessel security officer on a SOLAS ship and a member of the vessel personnel with or without security responsibilities on a SOLAS ship shall, if they hold a certificate of proficiency, ensure that their certificate is carried on board.
The operator of a vessel shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: establish an administrative and organizational structure for the security of the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide every person who has responsibilities under this Part with the support needed to fulfil his or her responsibilities;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: designate in writing a company security officer and a vessel security officer, by name or by position, other than the position for which the designation is being made;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: implement and maintain the vessel security plan, including any corrective action referred to in paragraph 209(h), and, if applicable, the marine facility security plan or the port security plan;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: provide the master with the following information:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the names of the parties responsible for appointing shipboard personnel, such as vessel management companies, crewing agents, contractors and concessionaires,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the names of the parties responsible for deciding the employment of the vessel, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: if the vessel is under a charter-party, the names of contact persons for the charter-party;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a SOLAS ship, ensure that the vessel security officer and vessel personnel with or without security responsibilities have the ability to maintain their effectiveness while performing their duties in accordance with the requirements set out

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of a ship that is entitled to fly the Canadian flag, in the safe manning document issued under section 202 of the Marine Personnel Regulations, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of a ship that is entitled to fly the flag of a foreign state, in the safe manning document issued by the contracting government of that state;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a vessel that is entitled to fly the Canadian flag, ensure that a vessel security plan is established;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the vessel security officer and vessel personnel with or without security responsibilities meet the training requirements set out in sections A-VI/5 and A-VI/6 of the STCW Code; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: clearly identify each restricted area on the vessel.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a SOLAS ship shall permanently mark the ship with the International Maritime Organization Ship Identification Number in accordance with Regulation 3 of Chapter XI-1 of SOLAS.

Nothing in this Part permits any person to constrain the master of a vessel from making or executing any decision that, in the professional judgment of the master, is necessary to maintain the safety and security of the vessel, including decisions

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to deny access to persons, other than operators and persons identified as authorized by a contracting government, or their goods;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to refuse to load cargo, including containers or other closed cargo transport units; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: to coordinate, with marine facility operators or port security officers, shore leave for vessel personnel or crew change, as well as access through marine facilities of visitors to the vessel, including representatives of seafarers’ welfare and labour organizations.

Subsection.Text: If a conflict between any safety and security requirements applicable to the vessel arises during its operations, the master shall give precedence to requirements intended to maintain the safety of the vessel and, in such a case, shall use any temporary procedures that the master determines appropriate under the circumstances and, to the highest possible degree, satisfy the security requirements of the prevailing MARSEC level.
If the master uses temporary procedures, the master shall, as soon as practicable, inform

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the vessel is in Canadian waters, a Marine Communications and Traffic Services Centre of the Canadian Coast Guard;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the vessel is a Canadian ship in the waters of a contracting government, the relevant maritime authority of that government and a Marine Communications and Traffic Services Centre of the Canadian Coast Guard; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the vessel is a Canadian ship in other waters, a Marine Communications and Traffic Services Centre of the Canadian Coast Guard.

Subsection.Text: The master shall provide the vessel security officer with the support necessary to carry out their duties on board the vessel.
The master shall ensure that the vessel security officer and vessel personnel with or without security responsibilities carry on board

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a SOLAS ship entitled to fly the Canadian flag, their certificates of proficiency issued under Part 8; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a SOLAS ship entitled to fly the flag of a foreign state, their certificates of proficiency issued by the contracting government of that state.

Subsection.Text: A company security officer may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: act in that capacity for more than one vessel if they are able to fulfil their responsibilities for each vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have other responsibilities within the vessel operator’s organization if they are able to fulfil the responsibilities of company security officer; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: delegate tasks required by this Part.

Subsection.Text: A company security officer remains responsible for the performance of the tasks they delegate.

Section.Text: A company security officer shall have, by training or job experience, knowledge and competence that is relevant to the industry in which the vessel operates and is in the following areas:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the administrative and organizational structure for the security of the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the operations and operating conditions of vessels, ports and marine facilities;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the security procedures of vessels, ports, port administrations and marine facilities, including the meanings and the requirements of the different MARSEC levels;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: emergency preparedness and response and contingency planning;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: security equipment and systems and their operational limitations;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: methods of conducting audits and inspections;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: access control and monitoring techniques;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: methods of conducting on site surveys and vessel security assessments;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: methods of conducting physical searches and non-intrusive inspections;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: conducting and assessing security drills and exercises, including exercises with marine facilities;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: techniques for security training and education;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: relevant international conventions, codes, standards and recommendations;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: relevant legislation, regulations and security measures, rules and procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: the responsibilities and functions of municipal, provincial and federal law enforcement agencies;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: methods for handling security-sensitive information and security-related communications;

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: current security threats and patterns;

Paragraph.Label: (q)
Paragraph.Text: the recognition and detection of weapons, explosives and incendiaries and other dangerous substances and devices;

Paragraph.Label: (r)
Paragraph.Text: the recognition of the characteristics and behavioural patterns of persons who are likely to threaten security; and

Paragraph.Label: (s)
Paragraph.Text: techniques that might be used to violate security procedures or to circumvent security procedures, equipment or systems.

Section.Text: A company security officer shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: provide the vessel security officer with information regarding security threats and other information relevant to the vessel’s security;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the vessel security assessment and any amendments are submitted to the Minister for approval;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the vessel security plan and any amendments are submitted to the Minister for approval;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the vessel security plan, as amended from time to time, is implemented;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that security drills and exercises are conducted;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the vessel’s security activities are audited;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: as soon as practicable after a deficiency in the vessel security plan is identified, amend the plan to correct the deficiency;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that corrective action is implemented as soon as practicable to correct any deficiency referred to in paragraph (g) until the vessel security plan is amended;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: ensure security awareness and vigilance on board the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that vessel personnel receive security training as required by this Part;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the security orientation referred to in section 214 is provided;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that there is effective communication and cooperation between the vessel and marine facilities or other vessels with which the vessel interfaces;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that there is consistency between the security requirements and the safety requirements;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: if a vessel security plan is prepared for more than one vessel, ensure that the plan takes into account the characteristics specific to each vessel; and

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a SOLAS ship, ensure that the safe manning document is applied in the development of security procedures.

Subsection.Text: A vessel security officer

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall be the master or a member of the crew;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: may also act as the vessel security officer for a vessel without a crew if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: they are able to fulfil their responsibilities for each vessel, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: each vessel’s security plan lists the other vessels for which they are responsible;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: may have other responsibilities within the vessel operator’s organization if they are able to fulfil the responsibilities of vessel security officer;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: may delegate tasks required by this Part; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a towing vessel, shall coordinate its security procedures with those of any vessels that it is towing or pushing.

Subsection.Text: A vessel security officer remains responsible for the performance of the tasks they delegate.
A vessel security officer shall have knowledge of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the layout of the vessel; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel security plan and its requirements.

Subsection.Text: A non-SOLAS ship’s vessel security officer shall have, by training or job experience, knowledge and competence that are relevant to the industry in which the vessel operates and are in the following areas:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: those set out for a company security officer in paragraphs 208(a) to (m) and (o) to (s);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: crowd management and control techniques; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the operation, testing, calibration and maintenance of security equipment and systems.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (6), a SOLAS ship’s vessel security officer shall hold

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a SOLAS ship that is entitled to fly the Canadian flag, a certificate of proficiency as a ship security officer issued under Part 8; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a SOLAS ship that is entitled to fly the flag of a foreign state, a certificate of proficiency as a ship security officer issued by the contracting government of that state.

Subsection.Text: In circumstances of exceptional necessity, when a person who holds a certificate of proficiency as a ship security officer is temporarily unavailable to serve as vessel security officer on a SOLAS ship, the Administration may permit a member of the vessel’s personnel who has responsibilities respecting the security of the vessel and an understanding of the vessel security plan to serve as vessel security officer on the vessel until it arrives at the next port of call or for a period not exceeding 30 days. That member shall serve as the vessel security officer as permitted by the Administration, and the vessel’s master shall, as soon as possible, inform the relevant maritime authorities of the next ports of call of the arrangements in place.

Section.Text: A vessel security officer shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: while the vessel is in operation, conduct inspections of the vessel at the frequency specified in the vessel security plan to ensure compliance with the requirements of this Part;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: implement the vessel security plan, as amended from time to time;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: conduct audits of the vessel security plan as required by this Part;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: coordinate the implementation of the vessel security plan with the company security officer and, if applicable, with the port security officer and the marine facility security officer;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: as soon as practicable after a deficiency in the vessel security plan is identified, report it to the company security officer and implement the action necessary that is required to correct the deficiency until the plan is amended;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: propose amendments to the vessel security plan to the company security officer to correct any deficiencies;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: ensure security awareness and vigilance on board the vessel, including awareness of changes in the MARSEC level and other circumstances that might affect work conditions on board;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that appropriate security training or orientation is provided to the vessel’s personnel in accordance with this Part;

Paragraph.Label: (h.1)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that all persons employed or engaged on board a vessel, including contractors, receive security orientation that is appropriate to their duties and the time they have spent on board the vessel, in order to be able to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: report a security incident,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: know the procedures to follow when there is a security threat, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: take part in security-related emergency and contingency procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (h.2)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that all vessel personnel with security responsibilities receive, before carrying out any of those responsibilities, security orientation that is appropriate to their duties;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: report security threats and security incidents to the master, the company security officer, the appropriate law enforcement agencies, the Minister and, if applicable, the port administration, as soon as possible after they occur so that an investigation can be conducted;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: report security breaches to the Minister and, if applicable, the port administration, as soon as possible after they occur;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that security equipment is operated, tested, calibrated and maintained in compliance with the vessel security plan; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: conduct security drills and exercises.

Subsection.Text: A member of the vessel personnel with security responsibilities on a SOLAS ship shall hold

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a SOLAS ship that is entitled to fly the Canadian flag, a certificate of proficiency as a member of the vessel personnel with security responsibilities issued under Part 8; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a SOLAS ship that is entitled to fly the flag of a foreign state, a certificate of proficiency as a member of the ship personnel with security responsibilities issued by the contracting government of that state.

Subsection.Text: In circumstances of exceptional necessity, if a member of the vessel personnel with security responsibilities is temporarily unavailable to fulfil his or her security responsibilities on a SOLAS ship, the Administration may permit a member of the vessel personnel without security responsibilities but with a knowledge of the vessel security plan to fulfil those responsibilities until the ship arrives at the next port of call or for a period not exceeding 30 days.

A member of the vessel personnel with security responsibilities on a non-SOLAS ship shall have, by training or job experience, knowledge and competence that are relevant to the industry in which the ship operates in any of the following areas that relate to the member’s responsibilities:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: current security threats and patterns;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the recognition and detection of weapons, explosives and incendiaries, and other dangerous substances and devices;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the recognition of the characteristics and behavioural patterns of persons who are likely to threaten security;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: techniques that could possibly be used to violate security procedures or to circumvent security procedures, equipment or systems;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: crowd management and control techniques;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: security-related communications;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: emergency preparedness and response and contingency planning;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the operation, testing, calibration and maintenance of security equipment and systems;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: inspection and monitoring techniques;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: methods of performing physical searches of persons and goods, including personal effects, baggage, ships’ stores and cargo;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the relevant provisions of the vessel security plan; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: the meanings and the requirements of the different MARSEC levels.

Subsection.Text: A member of the vessel personnel without security responsibilities on a SOLAS ship shall hold

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a SOLAS ship that is entitled to fly the Canadian flag, a certificate of proficiency as a member of the vessel personnel without security responsibilities issued under Part 8; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a SOLAS ship that is entitled to fly the flag of a foreign state, a certificate of proficiency as a member of the ship personnel without security responsibilities issued by the contracting government of that state.

Subsection.Text: A member of the vessel personnel without security responsibilities on a non-SOLAS ship, and a contractor engaged on the ship, shall receive security orientation that is appropriate to their duties and the amount of time that they have spent on board the ship. The security orientation shall address the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the meanings of the different MARSEC levels, the procedures at each level and the emergency procedures and contingency plans;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the recognition and detection of weapons, explosives and incendiaries, and other dangerous substances and devices;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the recognition of the characteristics and behavioural patterns of persons who are likely to threaten security; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: techniques that could possibly be used to violate security procedures or to circumvent security procedures, equipment or systems.

Section.Text: Security drills and exercises shall test the proficiency of vessel personnel in carrying out their assigned security responsibilities at all MARSEC levels and the effective implementation of the vessel security plan and shall enable the vessel security officer to identify any related security deficiencies that need to be rectified.

Subsection.Text: A security drill may be conducted with other drills, if appropriate, but shall be conducted at least once every three months, except in the case of a vessel that is entitled to fly the Canadian flag and that is not engaged on an international voyage or is not in service at the time that a drill is to be conducted, in which case the drill shall be conducted within one week after the beginning of an international voyage or the return to service.

Security drills shall test individual elements of the vessel security plan, including responses to security threats, security breaches and security incidents, and shall take into account, in respect of the vessel, the types of operations, personnel changes and other relevant circumstances.

If, at any given time, more than 25 per cent of the vessel’s permanent crew have not participated in a security drill on board the vessel within the previous three months, a security drill shall be conducted within one week.
A documented response to a security incident that was recorded under paragraph 218(1)(c) is considered equivalent to a security drill.
Security exercises

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall test the requirements of the vessel security plan that are relevant to the objectives of each exercise and shall involve the active participation of personnel on board the vessel as appropriate to the exercise;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: may include the participation of governmental authorities or personnel from marine facilities, port administrations or other vessels who have security responsibilities, depending on the scope and the nature of the exercises;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: may be performed with respect to only the vessel or as part of a cooperative program to test the vessel security plan of another vessel or a marine facility or port security plan; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: shall test, at a minimum, elements of coordination, resource availability, response, and communication and notification procedures.

Subsection.Text: Security exercises shall be conducted at least once every calendar year with no more than 18 months between them.
Security exercises may be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: full-scale;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a tabletop simulation or seminar;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: combined with other appropriate exercises; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a combination of two or more of the elements set out in paragraphs (a) to (c).

Subsection.Text: The implementation of security procedures at MARSEC level 2 or MARSEC level 3 is considered equivalent to a security exercise.
A vessel security officer shall keep the following records:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: details of security training, including the date, duration and description and the names of the participants;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: details of security drills and exercises, including the date and description, the names of the participants and any best practices or lessons learned that might improve the vessel security plan;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: details of security threats, security breaches and security incidents, including the date, time, location and description, the response to them and the person to whom they were reported;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: records of changes in the MARSEC level, including the date, the time that notification was received and the time of compliance with the requirements of the new level;

Paragraph.Label: (d.1)
Paragraph.Text: a record of the date on which, and the time at which, the vessel becomes subject to this Part and of the date on which, and the time at which, it ceases to be subject to this Part;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: records of maintenance, calibration and testing of equipment used for security, including the date and time of the activity and the equipment involved;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the last 10 declarations of security and of each continuing declaration of security for at least 90 days after the end of its effective period;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a SOLAS ship, a continuous synopsis record issued by the Minister;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a record of the last 10 calls at marine facilities;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: a record of each annual audit of the vessel security plan that includes, for each annual audit, a letter from the company security officer or the vessel security officer that certifies the day on which the audit was completed;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of the vessel security assessment and details of each periodic review of the vessel security assessment, including the date on which it was conducted and the findings of the review;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the approved vessel security plan and details of each periodic review of the vessel security plan, including the date on which it was conducted, the findings of the review and any amendments to the plan that are recommended;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: details of each amendment to the vessel security plan, including the date of its approval and of its implementation;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: a list, by name or position, of the vessel personnel who have security responsibilities;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: an up-to-date list containing the names of screening officers; and

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: records of inspections, including the date on which they are conducted.

Subsection.Text: If records respecting equipment that is not used exclusively for security are kept separately from records respecting equipment that is used exclusively for security, the vessel security officer shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: document, in written or electronic form, their existence, location and the name or position of the person responsible for keeping them; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the records are accessible.

Subsection.Text: The vessel security officer shall ensure that the records set out in subsection (1) are kept for at least two years after they are made and shall make them available to the Minister on request, but shall ensure that the copy of the vessel security assessment and the approved vessel security plan are kept for at least two years after the expiry of the plan.
The vessel security officer shall ensure that the records are protected from unauthorized access or disclosure.
The vessel security officer shall ensure that any records kept in electronic format are protected from deletion, destruction and revision.
No person shall disclose security information contained in the records, unless the disclosure is for the purpose of complying with these Regulations.

Heading.TitleText: MARSEC Level Coordination and Implementation of Procedures

Subsection.Text: The operator of a vessel shall, before the vessel interfaces with a marine facility, ensure that all procedures that are established in the vessel security plan for compliance with the MARSEC level in effect for that marine facility are implemented.
When notified of an increase in the MARSEC level, the master of a vessel shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the MARSEC level in effect at a marine facility with which the vessel is about to interface is raised to a level higher than the level in effect on the vessel, ensure that the vessel complies, without undue delay before interfacing with the facility, with all the procedures established in the vessel security plan for compliance with that higher MARSEC level;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the vessel is in Canadian waters, notify a Marine Communications and Traffic Services Centre of the Canadian Coast Guard if all the procedures established in the vessel security plan for compliance with that higher MARSEC level have not been implemented;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the vessel is a Canadian ship in the waters of a contracting government, notify the relevant maritime authority of that government;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: if the vessel is a Canadian ship in other waters, notify a Marine Communications and Traffic Services Centre of the Canadian Coast Guard; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: brief all vessel personnel on identified security threats, emphasize reporting procedures and stress the need for increased vigilance.

Subsection.Text: If there has been a change in the MARSEC level from that reported in the pre-arrival information required by section 221, the master shall immediately notify a Marine Communications and Traffic Services Centre of the Canadian Coast Guard.
The vessel security officer shall have the means to notify all vessel personnel of changes in security conditions on board the vessel.
The vessel shall have communication systems and procedures that allow for effective communications

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: between personnel with security responsibilities with respect to the vessel and marine facilities, ports and other vessels interfacing with the vessel; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: with the Minister and local law enforcement agencies.

Subsection.Text: The communication systems shall have a backup to ensure internal and external communications.

The master of a vessel shall ensure that the vessel does not enter Canadian waters unless the master reports pre-arrival information at the following time to the Minister in accordance with the instructions set out in the most recent edition of the Canadian Coast Guard Radio Aids to Marine Navigation:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the duration of the segment of the voyage before entering Canadian waters is less than 24 hours, as soon as practicable before entering Canadian waters but no later than the time of departure from the last port of call;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the duration of the segment of the voyage before entering Canadian waters is less than 96 hours but more than 24 hours, at least 24 hours before entering Canadian waters; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: at least 96 hours before entering Canadian waters.

Subsection.Text: The master of a vessel shall ensure that the following pre-arrival information in respect of the vessel is reported under subsection (1):

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: its name;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: its country of registry;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the name of its registered owner;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the name of its operator;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the name of its classification society;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: its international radio call sign;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the number of its International Ship Security Certificate or interim International Ship Security Certificate, of its Canadian Vessel Security Certificate or interim Canadian Vessel Security Certificate, or of its ship security compliance document or interim ship security compliance document;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: its International Maritime Organization ship identification number, if it is a SOLAS ship;

Paragraph.Label: (h.1)
Paragraph.Text: as applicable, the International Maritime Organization Unique Company Identification Number of its company and the International Maritime Organization Unique Registered Owner Identification Number of its owner, as defined in Regulation 3-1 of Chapter XI-1 of SOLAS;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the date of issuance, date of expiry and name of the issuing body of its International Ship Security Certificate or interim International Ship Security Certificate, of its Canadian Vessel Security Certificate or interim Canadian Vessel Security Certificate, or of its ship security compliance document or interim ship security compliance document;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: confirmation that the vessel has an approved vessel security plan;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the current MARSEC level;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of when its last 10 declarations of security were completed;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: details of any security breach, security incident or security threat involving the vessel during the last ten calls at marine facilities and during the time spent at sea between those calls;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: details of any deficiencies in its security equipment and systems, including the communication systems, and the way in which the master of the vessel intends to correct them;

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, the name of its agent and their 24-hour telephone and facsimile numbers;

Paragraph.Label: (q)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, the name of its charterer;

Paragraph.Label: (r)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which the information is reported and the latitude and longitude of the vessel at the time that it is reported;

Paragraph.Label: (s)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel’s course and speed;

Paragraph.Label: (t)
Paragraph.Text: its first port of call in Canada, with the estimated time of arrival at that port of call, and, if applicable, its final destination, with the estimated time of arrival at that destination;

Paragraph.Label: (u)
Paragraph.Text: the name of a contact person at the marine facility that it will visit and their 24-hour telephone and facsimile numbers;

Paragraph.Label: (v)
Paragraph.Text: the following information in respect of its last 10 marine facilities visited:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the receiving facility,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the marine facility visited,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the city and country,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the date and time of arrival, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the date and time of departure;

Paragraph.Label: (w)
Paragraph.Text: a general description of the cargo, including the cargo amount;

Paragraph.Label: (x)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, the presence and description of any dangerous substances or devices on board; and

Paragraph.Label: (y)
Paragraph.Text: the following contact information:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the name of the master,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: an email address, if applicable, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a satellite or cellular telephone number, if applicable.

Subsection.Text: If there is any change in the pre-arrival information reported under subsection (1), the master of a vessel shall ensure

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that the change is reported to the Minister in accordance with the instructions set out in the most recent edition of the Canadian Coast Guard publication entitled Radio Aids to Marine Navigation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that the vessel does not enter Canadian waters unless the change has been reported to the Minister; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a change that has occurred after the vessel has entered Canadian waters, that the change is reported to the Minister before the vessel’s first interface with a marine facility in Canada.

Subsection.Text: This section does not apply to vessels operating solely on the Great Lakes or to the portions of a vessel’s voyage on the Great Lakes after pre-arrival information has been given prior to its entrance into the St. Lawrence Seaway.
For the purposes of this section, a vessel is constructed on the earliest of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which its keel is laid,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which construction identifiable with a specific vessel begins, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which the assembly of the vessel reaches the lesser of 50 tonnes and 1 per cent of the estimated mass of all structural material of the vessel.

Subsection.Text: The operator of a vessel shall ensure that the vessel is equipped with a vessel security alert system

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: not later than the day of the first survey of its radio installation after July 1, 2004 if the vessel was constructed before July 1, 2004 and is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a passenger vessel, including a passenger high-speed craft, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: an oil tanker, a chemical tanker, a gas carrier, a bulk carrier or a cargo high-speed craft that is 500 tons gross tonnage or more;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: not later than the day of the first survey of its radio installation after July 1, 2006 if the vessel was constructed before July 1, 2004 and is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a cargo vessel, other than one referred to in subparagraph (a)(ii), that is 500 tons gross tonnage or more, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a mobile offshore drilling unit; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: before it is operated if the vessel was constructed on or after July 1, 2004.

Subsection.Text: A vessel’s radio installation may be used as the vessel security alert system if it meets the requirements of Chapter IV of SOLAS and those of sections 223 to 225.
The vessel security alert system shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be capable of being activated from the navigation bridge and at least one other location;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: comply with

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: International Maritime Organization Resolution MSC.136(76), annex 7, Performance Standards for a Ship Security Alert System, as amended from time to time, if the system was installed before July 1, 2004,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: International Maritime Organization Resolution MSC.147(77), annex 5, Performance Standards for a Ship Security Alert System, as amended from time to time, if the system is installed on or after July 1, 2004; or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: another performance standard that provides the same level of security as in subparagraph (i) or (ii); and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be equipped with activation points designed to prevent its inadvertent initiation.

Subsection.Text: For the purpose of interpreting the annexes referred to in paragraph (1)(b), “should” shall be read to mean “shall”.

Section.Text: The vessel security alert system, when activated,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall, if the security of the vessel is under threat or has been compromised, initiate and transmit a vessel-to-shore security alert to the nearest Canadian maritime rescue coordination centre identifying the vessel and its position and indicating that the security of the vessel is under threat or has been compromised;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shall not send a security alert to another vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: shall not raise an alarm on board the vessel; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: shall continue the security alert until it is deactivated or reset.

Subsection.Text: The radio system used for a vessel security alert system shall comply with relevant international standards.
If the vessel security alert system is powered from the vessel’s main source of electrical power, it shall also be possible to operate the system from another source of power.

Section.Text: If a Canadian maritime rescue coordination centre notifies the Minister that it has received a vessel security alert, the Minister shall immediately notify the contracting governments in the vicinity of which the vessel is operating and, in the case of a Canadian ship, its operator.

If a Canadian maritime rescue coordination centre notifies the Minister that it has received a vessel security alert from a vessel that is entitled to fly the flag of a foreign state, the Minister shall immediately notify the contracting government of that vessel and, if appropriate, of the countries in the vicinity of which the vessel is operating.

Subsection.Text: A declaration of security shall be completed before an interface starts between a vessel and a marine facility or another vessel if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: they are operating at different MARSEC levels;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: one of them does not have a security plan approved by a contracting government or by a security organization referred to in section 9.2 of Part A of the ISPS Code;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the interface involves a cruise ship, a vessel carrying certain dangerous cargoes or the loading or transfer of certain dangerous cargoes; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the security officer of either of them identifies security concerns about the interface.

Subsection.Text: A new declaration of security is required if there is a change in the MARSEC level.

The declaration of security shall provide a means for ensuring that all shared security concerns are fully addressed throughout the interface and shall contain the information set out in the form in Appendix 1 of Part B of the ISPS Code, with the terms “ship”, “port facility” and “security measures” read as “vessel”, “marine facility” and “security procedures”, respectively.
The declaration of security shall be in English or French and be signed by the vessel security officer and the marine facility security officer or the vessel security officers, as the case may be.

A vessel security officer or a marine facility security officer may authorize in writing a person who has security responsibilities on the vessel or marine facility and appropriate training to complete and sign the declaration of security on their behalf.

At MARSEC level 1 and MARSEC level 2, a continuing declaration of security may be used for multiple interfaces between a vessel and a marine facility or another vessel if the effective period of the declaration does not exceed

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 90 days at MARSEC level 1; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 30 days at MARSEC level 2.

Subsection.Text: If a declaration of security is required under subsection (1) between a vessel and the operator of a lock in the St. Lawrence Seaway, it shall be completed on its entry into the first lock and remain in effect until the vessel exits the St. Lawrence Seaway at the St. Lambert Lock or the Welland Canal at Port Colborne.

Section.Text: The persons who conduct a vessel security assessment shall have, collectively, the competence to evaluate the security of the vessel, including knowledge that is relevant to the industry in which the vessel operates, in the following areas:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: current security threats and patterns;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the detection and recognition of weapons, explosives and incendiaries and other dangerous substances and devices;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the recognition of the characteristics and behavioural patterns of persons who are likely to threaten security;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: techniques that might be used to violate security procedures or to circumvent security procedures, equipment or systems;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: methods used to cause a security incident;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the effects of dangerous substances and devices on vessels and their equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: vessel security requirements;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: vessel-to-vessel and vessel-to-marine facility interface business practices;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: emergency preparedness and response and contingency planning;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: physical security requirements;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: radio and telecommunications systems, including computer systems and networks;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: marine engineering; and

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: vessel and marine facility operations.

Section.Text: The company security officer shall ensure that the following security assessment information is provided to persons who conduct the on-site survey and vessel security assessment:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the general layout of the vessel, including the location of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: actual and potential points of access to the vessel and their function,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: areas that should have restricted access,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: essential maintenance equipment,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: stowage and cargo spaces, including storage areas for essential maintenance equipment, ships’ stores, cargo and unaccompanied baggage, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: ships’ stores;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: security threat assessments, including the purpose and methodology of the assessment, for the area in which the vessel operates or at which passengers embark or disembark and the types of cargo being carried by the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of any previous security assessment prepared for the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a list of the emergency and stand-by equipment available to maintain essential services;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: changes in the tide that might have an impact on the vulnerability or security of the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the number of vessel personnel, the security duties of persons with security responsibilities and existing security training requirements;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a list of existing security and safety equipment for the protection of personnel, visitors and passengers;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: details of escape and evacuation routes and assembly stations that have to be maintained to ensure the orderly and safe emergency evacuation of the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: copies of existing agreements with persons or organizations that provide security services; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: details of security procedures in effect, including inspection and access control procedures, identification systems, surveillance and monitoring equipment, personnel identification documents, communication, alarm, lighting, access control and other security systems.

Section.Text: The company security officer shall ensure that an on-site survey of the vessel is conducted that examines and evaluates protective measures, procedures and operations in effect on board the vessel to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ensure the performance of all vessel security duties;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: control access to the vessel through the use of identification systems or otherwise;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: control the embarkation of vessel personnel and other persons and their goods, including personal effects and baggage, whether accompanied or unaccompanied;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: supervise the handling of cargo and the delivery of ships’ stores;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: monitor restricted areas and other areas that have restricted access to ensure that only authorized persons have access;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: monitor the deck areas and areas adjacent to the vessel; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: ensure the ready availability of security communication systems, information and equipment.

Section.Text: The persons who conduct a vessel security assessment shall take into account the security assessment information, the on-site survey and the requirements of this Part and provide recommendations for security procedures that shall be established in the vessel security plan, including recommendations respecting

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: restricted areas;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: response procedures for fire or other emergency conditions;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: security supervision of all persons on board;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the frequency and effectiveness of security patrols;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: access control systems, including identification systems;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: security communication systems and procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: security doors, barriers and lighting;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: security and surveillance equipment and systems;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: potential security threats and the following types of security incidents:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: damage to, or destruction of, the vessel or an interfacing marine facility or vessel by explosive devices, arson, sabotage or vandalism,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: tampering with the essential equipment or systems, stores or cargo of the vessel,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the unauthorized access to or use of the vessel, including the presence of stowaways,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the smuggling on board of weapons, explosives, incendiaries or other dangerous substances or devices, including weapons of mass destruction,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the use of the vessel or its equipment as a weapon or as a means to cause damage or destruction,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the hijacking or seizure of the vessel or persons on board, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: attacks on the vessel while at berth, at anchor or at sea; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the evaluation of the potential of each identified point of access, including open decks, that could be used by individuals who might try to breach security, whether or not those individuals legitimately have access to the vessel.

Subsection.Text: The vessel security assessment shall be written in English or French and shall contain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a summary of how the on-site survey was conducted;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: details of existing security procedures and operations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a description of each vulnerability found during the assessment;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a description of security procedures that should be used to address each vulnerability;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a list of the key vessel operations that are important to protect;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: conclusions as to the likelihood of possible security threats to key vessel operations; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a list of identified weaknesses, including human factors, in the infrastructure, policies and procedures relating to the vessel.

Subsection.Text: A vessel security assessment shall address the following elements in respect of the vessel:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: its physical security;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: its structural integrity;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: personnel protection systems;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: security procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: its radio and telecommunication systems, including computer systems and networks; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: any other element on board the vessel that might, if damaged or used illicitly, pose a risk to people, property or operations on board the vessel or at a marine facility.

Subsection.Text: The vessel security assessment shall consider the security of all persons and the activities, services, operations, capacities and goods that are important to protect, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the capacity to maintain safe navigation and emergency response;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: cargo, particularly dangerous goods or substances;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ships’ stores;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
