Paragraph.Text: the vessel’s security communication and surveillance systems, if any; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any other security systems on the vessel.

Subsection.Text: The vessel security assessment shall take into account all possible vulnerabilities, including those resulting from

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any conflict between safety and security requirements;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any conflict between duties on board and security assignments;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the impact of watchkeeping duties and fatigue on vessel personnel alertness and performance;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: security training deficiencies;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: deficiencies in security equipment and systems, including communication systems; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the fact that the vessel was not subject to this Part before the start of an international voyage.

Subsection.Text: A vessel security plan shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: state the name of the vessel’s operator;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: identify the company security officer by name or, if they hold another position, by position, and provide 24-hour contact information;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of vessel entitled to fly the Canadian flag, be written in English or French;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: be based on the vessel security assessment;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: address each vulnerability identified in the vessel security assessment;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: establish that the vessel’s master has the overriding authority and responsibility to make decisions with respect to the security of the vessel and to request the assistance of the operator or contracting government when necessary; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: identify the locations of the vessel security alert system activation points.

Subsection.Text: The vessel security plan shall address the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: procedures designed to prevent weapons, explosives, incendiaries, dangerous substances and devices that are intended for use against persons, vessels or marine facilities and whose carriage is not authorized from being taken on board the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for the prevention of unauthorized access to the vessel that include the security procedures set out in sections 236 to 239 and, if applicable, sections 260 and 264;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for the establishment of restricted areas as provided for in section 240;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for preventing unauthorized access to restricted areas that include the security procedures set out in sections 241 to 243;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for cargo handling and for ships’ stores and bunkers that include the security procedures set out in sections 244 to 251;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for monitoring the vessel, the restricted areas on board the vessel and the area surrounding the vessel that include the security procedures set out in sections 252 to 255;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for responding to security threats, security breaches and security incidents, including provisions for maintaining critical operations of the vessel or for vessel and marine facility interfacing, that include the security procedures set out in section 256;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for responding to any security instructions a contracting government may give at MARSEC level 3 in respect of a specific security threat;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: other security procedures for each MARSEC level;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for evacuation in case of security threats, security breaches or security incidents;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: duties of shipboard personnel assigned security responsibilities and of other shipboard personnel on security related matters;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for auditing the security activities;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for training, drills and exercises associated with the plan;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for interfacing with marine facilities and other vessels at all MARSEC levels;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for declarations of security;

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for the periodic review of the plan and for updating it;

Paragraph.Label: (q)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for reporting security incidents;

Paragraph.Label: (r)
Paragraph.Text: procedures to ensure the inspection, testing, calibration and maintenance of any security equipment on board;

Paragraph.Label: (s)
Paragraph.Text: the frequency for testing or calibration of any security equipment on board;

Paragraph.Label: (t)
Paragraph.Text: the frequency of inspections of the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (u)
Paragraph.Text: procedures, instructions and guidance on the use of the vessel security alert system, including its testing, activation, deactivation and resetting and how to limit false alerts;

Paragraph.Label: (v)
Paragraph.Text: procedures to facilitate shore leave for vessel personnel or crew change;

Paragraph.Label: (w)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for overcoming any vulnerability resulting from the fact referred to in paragraph 233(4)(f); and

Paragraph.Label: (x)
Paragraph.Text: procedures to be followed when the vessel becomes subject to this Part and when it ceases to be subject to this Part.

Section.Text: The vessel security plan shall include the following individual sections and, if the plan does not list the sections in the following order, it shall contain an index that identifies the location of the sections:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: organizational structure for the security of the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: personnel training;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: drills and exercises;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: records and documentation;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: response to a change in the MARSEC level;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for interfacing with marine facilities and other vessels;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: declarations of security;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: communications;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: security systems and equipment maintenance;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: security procedures for access control;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: security procedures for restricted areas;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: security procedures for handling cargo;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: security procedures for delivery of ships’ stores and bunkers;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: security procedures for monitoring;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: procedures for security threats, security breaches and security incidents;

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: audits and vessel security plan amendments; and

Paragraph.Label: (q)
Paragraph.Text: vessel security assessment summary.

Subsection.Text: At all MARSEC levels, security procedures shall be established in the vessel security plan, to the extent that they are appropriate to the vessel’s operations, to control access to the vessel (in particular, access to ladders, access gangways, access ramps, access doors, side scuttles, windows and ports, hatches, mooring lines, anchor chains, cranes and hoisting gear) and to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: deter the unauthorized introduction of weapons, explosives and incendiaries and other dangerous substances and devices;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: carry out authorized screening; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: secure weapons, explosives and incendiaries and other dangerous substances and devices that are authorized to be on board.

Subsection.Text: The vessel security plan shall ensure that the following are established at each MARSEC level:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the type of restriction or prohibition to be applied and the means of enforcing it; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the means of identification required to allow persons to board the vessel and remain on the vessel without having their identity questioned.

Subsection.Text: The vessel security plan shall ensure that an identification system for verifying the identification of vessel personnel or other persons seeking to board the vessel is established that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: allows the identification of authorized persons, temporarily or permanently, at each MARSEC level;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is coordinated, when practicable, with identification systems at marine facilities used by the vessel; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is updated regularly.

Subsection.Text: The vessel security plan shall indicate the frequency of application of any security procedure for access control, particularly if the security procedure is applied on a random or occasional basis.

Section.Text: At MARSEC level 1, security procedures for access control shall be established in the vessel security plan, to the extent that they are appropriate to the vessel’s operations, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the authorized screening of persons and goods at a frequency specified in the plan;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: verifications of the identification of any person seeking to board the vessel and examining at least one of the following:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: joining instructions,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a passenger ticket,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a boarding pass,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: work orders or surveyor orders,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: governmental identification,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: a restricted area pass, or

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: visitor badges issued in accordance with an identification system;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the denial or revocation of a person’s authorization to be on board if the person is unable or unwilling, at the request of vessel personnel, to establish their identity or to account for their presence on board;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: reporting of any incident referred to in paragraph (c) to the company security officer, vessel security officer, marine facility security officer, port security officer, if applicable, and the appropriate law enforcement agencies;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: means to deter unauthorized access to the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the identification of access points that must have secured means of entry or be attended to deter unauthorized access;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the locking of, or the prevention in some other way of access to, unattended spaces that adjoin areas to which passengers and visitors have access;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the provision of a designated secure area on board or, in liaison with a marine facility, at a marine facility, for conducting the authorized screening of persons and goods;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the authorized screening of vessel personnel or their goods by other vessel personnel, if it is clearly required for security reasons;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the segregation of persons who and their goods that have been through authorized screening from other persons and their goods;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the segregation of embarking passengers from disembarking passengers;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: the authorized screening before loading, at the frequency specified in the vessel security plan and in liaison with a marine facility, of a defined percentage of vehicles to be loaded aboard a passenger vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: the authorized screening before loading, in liaison with a marine facility, of all unaccompanied vehicles to be loaded on a passenger vessel; and

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: a response to the presence of unauthorized persons on board, including the expulsion of unauthorized boarders.

Section.Text: At MARSEC level 2, additional security procedures for access control shall be established in the vessel security plan, to the extent that they are appropriate to the vessel’s operations, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an increase in the frequency and detail of the authorized screening of persons and goods;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the authorized screening of all unaccompanied baggage by means of X-ray equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the assignment of additional personnel to patrol deck areas during periods of reduced vessel operations to deter unauthorized access;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a reduction in the number of access points to the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the denial of access to visitors who do not have a verified destination;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the deterrence of waterside access to the vessel, which may include, in liaison with a marine facility or a port administration, providing boat patrols; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: if the vessel is at a marine facility, the establishment of a restricted area on the shoreside of the vessel, in close cooperation with the facility.

Section.Text: At MARSEC level 3, additional security procedures for access control shall be established in the vessel security plan, to the extent that they are appropriate to the vessel’s operations, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the authorized screening of all persons and goods;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the performance of one or more of the following procedures on unaccompanied baggage:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: more extensive authorized screening, such as X-raying it from two or more angles,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: preparing to restrict or suspend handling it, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: refusing to accept it on board;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: preparation for cooperating with response organizations and marine facilities;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the limitation of access to the vessel to a single, controlled access point;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the granting of access to only those responding to the security incident or security threat;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the suspension of embarkation or disembarkation activities;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the suspension of operations related to cargo;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the evacuation of the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the movement of the vessel; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the preparation for a full or partial search of the vessel.

Subsection.Text: At all MARSEC levels, security procedures for restricted areas shall be established in the vessel security plan, to the extent that they are appropriate to the vessel’s operations, in order to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prevent or deter unauthorized access;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: protect the vessel, security areas within the vessel, security and surveillance equipment and systems and persons authorized to be on board; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: protect cargo and ships’ stores from tampering.

Subsection.Text: Restricted areas shall be established for the following areas:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the navigation bridge, machinery spaces and other control stations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: spaces containing the central controls for security and surveillance equipment and systems and spaces that contain the central lighting system controls;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ventilation and air-conditioning systems and other similar spaces;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: spaces with access to potable water tanks, pumps or manifolds;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: spaces containing dangerous goods or hazardous substances;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: spaces containing cargo pumps and their controls;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: cargo spaces and spaces containing ships’ stores;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: crew accommodations; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: any other spaces or areas vital to the security of the vessel.

Subsection.Text: The vessel security plan shall contain procedures to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: identify vessel personnel who are authorized to have access;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: determine the persons other than vessel personnel who are authorized to have access;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: determine the conditions under which vessel personnel or other persons are authorized to have access;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: define the extent of any restricted area;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: establish the times when access restrictions apply; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: post notices in accordance with section 21 of the Act.

Section.Text: At MARSEC level 1, the following security procedures for restricted areas shall be established in the vessel security plan, to the extent that they are appropriate to the vessel’s operations:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the locking or securing of access points;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the monitoring and use of surveillance equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the use of guards or patrols; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the use of automatic intrusion detection devices to alert vessel personnel to unauthorized access by the activation of an audible or visual alarm at a location that is continuously attended or monitored.

Section.Text: At MARSEC level 2, the following additional security procedures for restricted areas shall be established in the vessel security plan, to the extent that they are appropriate to the vessel’s operations:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an increase in the frequency and intensity of monitoring and access controls on existing restricted areas;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the establishment of restricted areas adjacent to access points;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the continuous monitoring of each area, using surveillance equipment; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the assignment of additional personnel to guard or patrol each area.

Section.Text: At MARSEC level 3, the following additional security procedures for restricted areas shall be established in the vessel security plan, to the extent that they are appropriate to the vessel’s operations:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the establishment of additional restricted areas on the vessel in proximity to the location of a security incident or the presumed location of a security threat; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: searches of restricted areas as part of a security sweep of the vessel.

Subsection.Text: At all MARSEC levels, security procedures in relation to cargo handling shall be established in the vessel security plan, to the extent that they are appropriate to the vessel’s operations, in order to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: deter and detect tampering;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: prevent cargo that is not meant for carriage from being accepted and stored on board the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: identify cargo that is approved for loading onto the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: include inventory control procedures at access points to the vessel; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: be able to inspect cargo for dangerous substances and devices at a frequency specified in the plan by one or more of the following means:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: visual examination,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: physical examination,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: detection devices such as scanners, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: canines.

Subsection.Text: The company security officer or vessel security officer may, with the agreement of the marine facility security officer and, if applicable, the port security officer, make arrangements with shippers or others responsible for the cargo with respect to off-site inspection, sealing, scheduling, supporting documentation and similar matters. The company security officer or vessel security officer, as the case may be, shall inform the marine facility security officer and, if applicable, the port security officer of any arrangement.

Section.Text: At MARSEC level 1, the following security procedures in relation to cargo handling shall be established in the vessel security plan, to the extent that they are appropriate to the vessel’s operations:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the routine inspection, including for evidence of tampering, of cargo and cargo spaces before and during cargo handling, except where it is unsafe to do so;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: verification that cargo to be loaded matches the cargo documentation or that cargo markings or container numbers match the information provided with shipping documents;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: inspection before loading, in accordance with the frequency specified in the plan and in liaison with marine facilities, of vehicles to be loaded on board ro-ro vessels, car-carriers and passenger vessels; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: verification, in liaison with marine facilities, of seals or other means used to prevent tampering.

Section.Text: At MARSEC level 2, the following additional security procedures in relation to cargo handling shall be established in the vessel security plan, to the extent that they are appropriate to the vessel’s operations:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an increase in the frequency and detail of inspecting cargo and cargo spaces;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: intensified inspections to ensure that only the intended cargo, container or other cargo transport units are loaded;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: intensified inspections of vehicles to be loaded on board ro-ro vessels, car-carriers and passenger vessels;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: increases, in liaison with the marine facility, in the frequency and detail of inspections of seals or other means used to prevent tampering;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: increases in the frequency of the use of detection devices, such as scanners, or canines; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the coordination of enhanced security procedures with the shipper or other responsible party in accordance with an established agreement and procedures.

Section.Text: At MARSEC level 3, the following additional security procedures in relation to cargo handling shall be established in the vessel security plan, to the extent that they are appropriate to the vessel’s operations:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the suspension of loading or unloading of cargo;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: preparation for cooperation with response organizations and marine facilities; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a verification of the inventory and location of any hazardous substances carried on board.

Heading.TitleText: Security Procedures for Delivery of Ships’ Stores and Bunkers

Subsection.Text: At all MARSEC levels, security procedures for the delivery of ships’ stores and bunkers shall be established in the vessel security plan, to the extent that they are appropriate to the vessel’s operations, in order to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: inspect ships’ stores for package integrity;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: prevent ships’ stores from being accepted without inspection;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: prevent tampering; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: prevent ships’ stores and bunkers from being accepted without being ordered.

Subsection.Text: If a vessel routinely uses a marine facility, the vessel security plan may establish standing procedures involving the vessel, its suppliers and the marine facility regarding notification and the timing of deliveries and their documentation.

Section.Text: At MARSEC level 1, the following security procedures with respect to the delivery of ships’ stores and bunkers shall be established in the vessel security plan, to the extent that they are appropriate to the vessel’s operations:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the inspection of ships’ stores before they are accepted;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: verification that ships’ stores and bunkers match the order before being brought on board or being bunkered; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the immediate securing of ships’ stores following delivery.

Section.Text: At MARSEC level 2, the following additional security procedures with respect to the delivery of ships’ stores shall be established in the vessel security plan, to the extent that they are appropriate to the vessel’s operations:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: intensified inspections of ships’ stores during delivery; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the inspection of ships’ stores before they are received on board.

Section.Text: At MARSEC level 3, the following additional security procedures with respect to the delivery of ships’ stores and bunkers shall be established in the vessel security plan, to the extent that they are appropriate to the vessel’s operations:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: more extensive inspections of ships’ stores; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the restriction or suspension of handling of ships’ stores and bunkers or refusal to accept them on board.

Subsection.Text: At all MARSEC levels, security procedures shall be established in the vessel security plan, to the extent that they are appropriate to the vessel’s operations, to continuously monitor the vessel, the restricted areas on board the vessel and the area surrounding the vessel through a combination of lighting, watchkeepers, security guards, deck watches, automatic intrusion-detection devices, surveillance equipment and waterborne patrols.
The following shall be considered when establishing the appropriate level and location of lighting:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: vessel personnel shall be able to detect activities on and around the vessel, on both the shoreside and the waterside;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the lighting shall facilitate personnel identification at access points;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the lighting may be provided through coordination with a marine facility or port administration; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: when lighting is necessary and the vessel is underway, the lighting shall be the maximum available that is consistent with safe navigation, taking into account the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea, 1972.

Subsection.Text: At MARSEC level 1, the following security procedures for monitoring the vessel shall be established in the vessel security plan, to the extent that they are appropriate to the vessel’s operations:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: preparing to conduct emergency searches of the ship;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: identifying and fixing any system failures or malfunctions of monitoring equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: continual monitoring of any automatic intrusion detection device that sets off an audible or visual alarm, or both; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: lighting the deck and vessel access points during the period between sunset and sunrise and periods of limited visibility sufficiently to allow the visual identification of persons seeking to board the vessel.

Subsection.Text: These security procedures may be coordinated with a marine facility or a port administration.

Section.Text: At MARSEC level 2, the following additional security procedures for monitoring the vessel shall be established in the vessel security plan, to the extent that they are appropriate to the vessel’s operations:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an increase in the frequency and detail of security patrols;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an increase in the coverage and intensity of lighting;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the use of or the increased use of security and surveillance equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the assignment of additional personnel as security lookouts; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the coordination of monitoring with boat patrols, and with foot or vehicle patrols, if provided by a marine facility or a port administration.

Section.Text: At MARSEC level 3, the following additional security procedures for monitoring the vessel shall be established in the vessel security plan, to the extent that they are appropriate to the vessel’s operations:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: cooperation with response organizations, marine facilities and port administrations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: switching on all lights on the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the illumination of the vicinity of the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the use of all surveillance equipment capable of recording activities on, or in the vicinity of, the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the maximization of the length of time the surveillance equipment can continue to record;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: preparations to conduct an underwater inspection of the hull; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: measures to deter underwater access to the hull, including slow revolutions of the vessel’s propellers, if practicable.

Heading.TitleText: Security Procedures for Security Threats, Security Breaches and Security Incidents

Section.Text: At all MARSEC levels, security procedures shall be established in the vessel security plan, as appropriate to the vessel’s operations, for the vessel security officer and persons who have security responsibilities with respect to the vessel to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: respond to security threats, security breaches and security incidents and maintain critical vessel and vessel-to-facility interface operations, including by

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: prohibiting entry into the affected area,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: denying access to the vessel, except to persons responding to the threat, breach or incident,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: implementing MARSEC level 3 security procedures throughout the vessel,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: stopping cargo-handling operations, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: notifying shoreside authorities or other vessels of the threat, breach or incident;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: evacuate the vessel in case of security threats, security breaches or security incidents, if the life of persons on board is threatened;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: report any security threats or security incidents involving the vessel to the Minister without undue delay;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: brief vessel personnel on potential security threats and the need for vigilance and their assistance in reporting suspicious persons, objects or activities; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: suspend non-critical operations in order to focus response on critical operations.

Subsection.Text: The company security officer shall submit a vessel security plan to the Minister

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a voyage that started before July 1, 2004, no later than July 1, 2004;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a voyage that starts after June 30, 2004 and before September 1, 2004, before the voyage starts; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a voyage that starts on or after September 1, 2004, at least 60 days before the voyage starts.

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall approve a vessel security plan that meets the requirements of sections 234 and 235.

Subject to subsection 259(5), a plan is valid for the period fixed by the Minister, not exceeding five years after the date on which it is approved by the Minister. In fixing the period, the Minister shall consider the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel’s operations and the industry in which it operates;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel’s ports of call and usual routes;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the operator’s security record;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel’s security record;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the complexity of the vessel security plan and the details of its procedures; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the findings of the vessel security assessment.

Subsection.Text: The company security officer shall ensure that an audit of the vessel security plan is performed annually.
If the plan meets the requirements of sections 234 and 235, the company security officer shall attach a letter to it certifying that it meets those requirements.

The company security officer shall ensure that an audit of the vessel security plan is performed if there is a new operator or if there have been modifications to the vessel, including to its physical structure, emergency response procedures or security procedures or operations. An audit of the plan as a result of modifications to the vessel may be limited to the provisions of the plan affected by the modifications.
Persons that perform audits of the security procedures established in the vessel security plan

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall have knowledge of the methods of conducting audits and inspections and control access and monitoring techniques; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shall be independent of the security procedures being audited unless that is impracticable because of the size and nature of the vessel.

Subsection.Text: If an audit finds that the vessel security plan no longer meets the requirements of sections 234 and 235, the vessel security officer shall ensure that amendments are submitted to the company security officer within 30 days after the day on which the audit is completed.

The operator of a vessel may make amendments to a vessel security plan approved under section 257. The operator shall submit the amendments to the Minister 30 days, or any shorter period that the Minister allows, before the day on which they are to take effect.

The operator of a vessel shall submit amendments to the Minister within 60 days after the day on which the Minister informs the operator in writing that a vessel security plan approved under section 257 no longer meets the requirements of sections 234 and 235.

The Minister shall approve the amended plan if it meets the requirements of sections 234 and 235, unless approving the plan is not in the public interest and is likely to adversely affect marine transportation security.

If amendments are required under subsection (1) or (3) and they are not submitted or the amended plan is not approved, the plan ceases to be valid on the day on which the operator of the vessel receives notification that the plan is no longer valid.

Heading.TitleText: Additional and Alternative Requirements in respect of Passenger Vessels and Ferries

Subsection.Text: In this section, passenger vessel does not include a cruise ship.

At all MARSEC levels, after any period during which a passenger vessel or a ferry was unattended, its vessel security officer shall ensure that security sweeps are performed in order to confirm the absence of security threats, dangerous substances or devices before the vessel gets underway.

At MARSEC level 1, instead of the identification verifications and authorized screening requirements referred to in paragraphs 237(a), (b) and (h), the vessel security plan of a passenger vessel or a ferry may establish

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: security procedures to search selected areas before passengers embark; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at least one of the following security procedures:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: conducting routine security patrols,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: using additional closed-circuit video cameras to monitor passenger areas, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: securing all non-passenger areas.

Subsection.Text: At MARSEC level 2, the vessel security plan of a passenger vessel or a ferry shall establish security procedures to search selected areas before passengers embark and, if the plan is establishing procedures under subsection (3), to increase the patrols and monitoring referred to in paragraph (3)(b) and the security sweeps referred to in subsection (2).

At MARSEC level 3, if the vessel security plan of a passenger vessel or a ferry has established procedures under subsection (3), the plan shall establish random enhanced security patrols, which need not consist of vessel personnel.

Heading.TitleText: Additional Requirements in respect of Cruise Ships

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), no person shall possess or carry a weapon, explosives or incendiaries on board a cruise ship.
Members of a law enforcement agency in the performance of their duties may possess or carry a weapon on board a cruise ship.

Persons who are engaged in the handling or transportation of cash, negotiable instruments or other valuable goods and who require firearms to protect their lives in the course of that handling or transportation may possess or carry firearms on board a cruise ship that is docked when they are handling or transporting the goods on behalf of the cruise ship operator.
Every cruise ship operator shall ensure that authorized screening of each person and their goods is carried out to ensure compliance with subsection (1).

Section.Text: A person who is embarking on or is on board a cruise ship shall not falsely declare

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that they are carrying, or have in their goods, a weapon, explosives or incendiaries;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that another person who is embarking on or is on board a cruise ship is carrying, or has in their goods, a weapon, explosives or incendiaries; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: that weapons, explosives or incendiaries have been placed on board a cruise ship.

Subsection.Text: A cruise ship operator shall remove from duty a screening officer who does not conduct an authorized screening in accordance with any security measures that may be formulated under section 7 of the Act and shall not allow the screening officer to conduct any authorized screening before the screening officer is retrained to meet the standards described in the measures.
A cruise ship operator shall maintain an up-to-date list containing the names of screening officers and shall provide the list to the Minister on request.

Section.Text: At all MARSEC levels, the cruise ship operator shall establish the following security procedures to control access to the cruise ship:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: security patrols; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: searches of selected areas before passengers embark and before the vessel gets underway.

Section.Text: When the MARSEC level is raised to MARSEC level 3, the vessel security officer of a cruise ship shall ensure that security briefs are provided to passengers about the security threat that resulted in the MARSEC level being raised, except where passengers might be put in danger.
The operator of a SOLAS ship or a non-SOLAS ship shall not allow a person to board the ship unless the person is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a member of the crew of the ship;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a contractor or service provider engaged to perform work on the ship;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a person referred to in any of paragraphs 267(1)(a) to (e); or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any other person authorized by the operator or the master of the ship to come on board.

Subsection.Text: No person shall enter or remain in a restricted area on a SOLAS ship or a non-SOLAS ship unless the person is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a member of the crew authorized to do so in accordance with the security procedures established in the vessel security plan;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a person other than a member of the crew who is escorted by an individual authorized to do so in accordance with the security procedures established in the vessel security plan;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an inspector designated under subsection 22(1) of the Act who is on duty;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a member of any of the following groups who is on duty on board the ship or at a marine facility during an interface with the ship:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: any police force in Canada,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the Canadian Security Intelligence Service,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the Canadian Forces within the meaning of Part II of the National Defence Act, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the Canada Border Services Agency; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a provider of emergency services who requires access to the restricted area for the protection and preservation of life or property.

Subsection.Text: No person shall provide another person with access to a restricted area or assistance in entering a restricted area unless that other person is a person referred to in any of paragraphs (1)(a) to (e).
A person who is being escorted in a restricted area shall remain with the escort while in the restricted area.

An escort shall remain with the person being escorted, or ensure that another person who is authorized to do so under the security plan acts as the escort, while the person being escorted is in the restricted area.
In this section, offshore facility means a marine facility in a maritime zone of Canada as described in Part I of the Oceans Act and includes a drilling unit and platform.
This Part applies to marine facilities, other than offshore facilities, that interface with vessels to which Part 2 applies.
The operator of a marine facility shall ensure that the requirements of this Part are met.
The operator of an occasional-use marine facility shall ensure that the requirements of sections 315 and 355 to 360.1 are met.

Section.Text: The operator of a marine facility shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: establish an administrative and organizational structure for security at the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide every person who has responsibilities under this Part with the support needed to fulfil their responsibilities;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: designate in writing a marine facility security officer by name or by a position other than the position for which the designation is being made;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: operate the marine facility in compliance with the marine facility security plan and, if applicable, any corrective action referred to in paragraph 306(e) or a port security plan;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: submit the security assessment information to the Minister;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the implementation of security procedures is coordinated with the vessels with which the marine facility interfaces and, if the facility is in a port, with the port administration;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: if the marine facility is in a port, ensure the participation of the marine facility security officer in the port security committee;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: if the marine facility is in a port, ensure that the marine facility security officer develops a marine facility security plan with the port security officer and in consultation with representatives of appropriate law enforcement agencies, emergency response providers, employers and labour at the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: coordinate, with the master of a vessel and, if the marine facility is in a port, the port security officer, shore leave for vessel personnel or crew change, as well as access through the marine facility of visitors to vessels, including representatives of seafarers’ welfare and labour organizations;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: provide information respecting the security of the marine facility to those persons who need it to comply with these Regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: clearly mark with signs each restricted area at the marine facility.

Subsection.Text: A marine facility security officer may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: act in that capacity for more than one marine facility if they are able to fulfil the responsibilities for each marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have other responsibilities within the marine facility operator’s organization if they are able to fulfil the responsibilities of marine facility security officer; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: delegate tasks required by this Part.

Subsection.Text: A marine facility security officer remains responsible for the performance of the tasks they delegate.

Section.Text: A marine facility security officer shall have, by training or job experience, knowledge and competence that is relevant to the industry in which the marine facility operates and is in the following areas:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the administrative and organizational structure for security at the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the operations and operating conditions of the marine facility, vessels and if applicable, port;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the security procedures of the marine facility, vessels and, if applicable, port, including the meaning and the requirements of the different MARSEC levels;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: emergency preparedness and response and contingency planning;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: security equipment and systems and their operational limitations;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: methods of conducting audits and inspections;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: access control and monitoring techniques;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: methods of conducting on-site surveys and marine facility security assessments;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: methods of conducting physical searches and non-intrusive inspections;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: conducting and assessing security drills and exercises, including exercises with vessels;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: techniques for security training and education;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: relevant international conventions, codes, standards and recommendations;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: relevant legislation, regulations and security measures, rules and procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: the responsibilities and functions of municipal, provincial and federal law enforcement agencies;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: methods of handling security-sensitive information and security-related communications;

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: current security threats and patterns;

Paragraph.Label: (q)
Paragraph.Text: the recognition and detection of weapons, explosives and incendiaries and other dangerous substances and devices;

Paragraph.Label: (r)
Paragraph.Text: the recognition of the characteristics and behavioural patterns of persons who are likely to threaten security;

Paragraph.Label: (s)
Paragraph.Text: techniques that might be used to violate security procedures or to circumvent security procedures, equipment or systems;

Paragraph.Label: (t)
Paragraph.Text: crowd management and control techniques; and

Paragraph.Label: (u)
Paragraph.Text: the operation, testing, calibration and maintenance of security equipment and systems.

Section.Text: A marine facility security officer shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: conduct inspections of the marine facility at the rate specified in the marine facility security plan to ensure compliance with the requirements of this Part;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: submit a marine facility security plan and any amendment to the Minister for approval;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: implement and maintain the approved marine facility security plan, coordinating it when necessary with the security officer of interfacing vessels and the port security officer;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: conduct audits of the marine facility security plan in accordance with this Part;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: as soon as practicable after a deficiency in the marine facility security plan is identified, implement the corrective action that is required to correct the deficiency until the plan is amended;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: submit to the Minister amendments to the marine facility security plan to correct any deficiencies;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: implement the approved amendments in the marine facility security plan;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: ensure security awareness and vigilance at the marine facility, including awareness of changes in the MARSEC level and other circumstances that might affect work conditions at the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that appropriate security training or orientation is provided to personnel at the marine facility in accordance with this Part;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: report security threats and security incidents to the appropriate law enforcement agencies, the Minister and, if applicable, the port administration, as soon as possible after they occur so that an investigation can be conducted;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: report security breaches to the Minister and, if applicable, the port administration, as soon as possible after they occur;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that there is effective communication and cooperation between the marine facility and the vessels with which it interfaces;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that security equipment is operated, tested, calibrated and maintained in compliance with the marine facility security plan;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: record and report the implementation of security procedures, after a change in the MARSEC level, to the Minister, to the operator of any vessel with which it is interfacing or about to interface and to the operator of any marine facility or port administration affected by the change;

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: keep a copy of the marine facility security assessment and plan readily accessible; and

Paragraph.Label: (p)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that security drills and exercises are conducted.

Heading.TitleText: Marine Facility Personnel with Security Responsibilities

Subsection.Text: Persons who have responsibilities respecting the security of a marine facility, other than the marine facility security officer, shall have, by training or job experience, knowledge that is relevant to the marine facility in the areas that relate to their responsibilities.
The areas of knowledge include the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: current security threats and patterns;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the recognition and detection of weapons, explosives and incendiaries and other dangerous substances and devices;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the recognition of the characteristics and behavioural patterns of persons who are likely to threaten security;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: techniques that might be used to violate security procedures or to circumvent security procedures, equipment or systems;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: crowd management and control techniques;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: security-related communications;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: emergency preparedness and response and contingency planning;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the operation, testing, calibration and maintenance of security equipment and systems;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: inspection and monitoring techniques;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: methods of performing physical searches of persons and goods, including personal effects, baggage, ships’ stores and cargo;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the relevant provisions of the marine facility security plan; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: the meaning and the requirements of the different MARSEC levels.

Heading.TitleText: Marine Facility Personnel without Security Responsibilities

Section.Text: A person who is assigned to a marine facility and who does not have security responsibilities shall receive security orientation in

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: basic security issues and communications;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the meaning and the requirements of the different MARSEC levels, the different procedures required of the person at each level and the emergency procedures and contingency plans;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the recognition and detection of weapons, explosives and incendiaries and other dangerous substances and devices;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the recognition of the characteristics and behavioural patterns of persons who are likely to threaten security; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: techniques that might be used to violate security procedures or to circumvent security procedures, equipment or systems.

Section.Text: Security drills and exercises shall test the proficiency of marine facility personnel in carrying out their assigned security responsibilities at all MARSEC levels and the effective implementation of the marine facility security plan and shall enable the marine facility security officer to identify any related security deficiencies that need to be corrected.

Subsection.Text: A security drill is conducted

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at least once every three months; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: within one month after operations resume at a marine facility that has been out of service or inactive for more than three months.

Subsection.Text: Security drills shall test individual elements of the marine facility security plan, including the response to security threats, security breaches and security incidents, and shall take into account, in respect of the marine facility, the types of operations, personnel changes, the types of vessels interfacing with it and other relevant circumstances.
A documented response to a security incident that was recorded under paragraph 312(1)(c) is considered equivalent to a security drill.
Security exercises

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall test the requirements of the marine facility security plan that are relevant to the objectives of each exercise, and shall involve the active participation of marine facility personnel as appropriate to the exercise;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: may involve the participation of governmental authorities or personnel from vessels, other marine facilities or port administrations who have security responsibilities, depending on the scope and the nature of the exercise;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: may be performed only with respect to the marine facility or as part of a cooperative program to test the security plan of another marine facility or the security plan of a vessel or a port; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: shall test, at a minimum, elements of coordination, resource availability, response, and communication and notification procedures.

Subsection.Text: Security exercises shall be conducted at least once every calendar year with no more than 18 months between them.
Exercises may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be full-scale or live;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be a tabletop simulation or seminar;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be combined with other appropriate exercises; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: be a combination of two or more of the elements set out in paragraphs (a) to (c).

Subsection.Text: If a marine facility is involved in the implementation of MARSEC level 2 or MARSEC level 3 following a security incident, the implementation of the MARSEC level is considered equivalent to a security exercise.
A marine facility security officer shall keep

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: records of security training, including the date, the duration and description and the names of the participants;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: records of security drills and exercises, including the date and description, the names of the participants and any best practices or lessons learned that might improve the marine facility security plan;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: records of security threats, security breaches and security incidents, including the date, time, location and description, the response to them and the person to whom they were reported;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: records of changes in the MARSEC level, including the date, the time that notification was received and the time of compliance with the requirements of the new level;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: records of maintenance, calibration and testing of equipment used for security, including the date and time of the activity and the equipment involved;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: declarations of security in respect of the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: internal audits and reviews of security activities;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: security assessment information;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the marine facility security assessment and each periodic review of the assessment, including the date on which the review was conducted and its findings;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the marine facility security plan and each periodic review of the plan, including the date on which the review was conducted, its findings and any recommended amendments to the plan;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: each amendment to the marine facility security plan, including the date of its approval and implementation;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: records of inspections and patrols;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: a list, by name or position, of the persons who have security responsibilities;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: an up-to-date list containing the names of screening officers; and

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: an up-to-date list, by name and position, of the holders of transportation security clearances, except in a case where a port administration keeps the list.

Subsection.Text: If records respecting equipment that is not used exclusively for security are kept separately from records respecting equipment that is used exclusively for security, the marine facility security officer shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: document, in written or electronic form, their existence, location and the name or position of the person responsible for keeping them; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the records are accessible.

Subsection.Text: The marine facility security officer shall ensure that the records or documents listed in subsection (1) are kept for at least two years after the day on which they are made and shall make them available to the Minister on request, but shall ensure that the marine facility security plan, and the assessment on which it was based, are kept for at least two years after the day on which the plan expires.
The marine facility security officer shall ensure that the records are protected from unauthorized access or disclosure.
The marine facility security officer shall ensure that any records kept in electronic format are protected from deletion, destruction and revision.
No person shall disclose security information contained in the records, unless the disclosure is for the purpose of complying with these Regulations.
The marine facility security officer shall have the means to notify all marine facility personnel of changes in security conditions at the marine facility.
The marine facility shall have communication systems and procedures that allow effective communications

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: between the marine facility security personnel and vessels interfacing with the marine facility and, if the marine facility is in a port, the port administration; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: with the Minister and local law enforcement agencies.

Subsection.Text: The communication systems shall have a backup to ensure internal and external communications.

Heading.TitleText: Coordination of Security Procedures during Interfacing

Section.Text: The operator of a marine facility shall ensure that the implementation of the marine facility security procedures is coordinated with vessels interfacing with the marine facility and, if the marine facility is in a port, with the port administration.

Subsection.Text: A declaration of security shall be completed before an interface starts between a marine facility and a vessel if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: they are operating at different MARSEC levels;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: one of them does not have a security plan approved by a contracting government;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the interface involves a cruise ship, a vessel carrying certain dangerous cargoes or the loading or transfer of certain dangerous cargoes; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the security officer of either of them identifies security concerns about the interface.

Subsection.Text: A new declaration of security is required if there is a change in the MARSEC level.

The declaration of security shall provide a means for ensuring that all shared security concerns are fully taken into account throughout the interface and shall contain the information set out in the form in Appendix 1 of Part B of the ISPS Code, with the terms “ship”, “port facility” and “security measures” read as “vessel”, “marine facility” and “security procedures”, respectively.
The declaration of security shall be in English or French and be signed by the marine facility security officer and the vessel security officer.

A marine facility security officer or vessel security officer may authorize in writing a person who has security responsibilities at the marine facility or on the vessel and appropriate training to complete and sign the declaration of security on their behalf.

At MARSEC level 1 and MARSEC level 2, a continuing declaration of security may be used for multiple interfaces between a marine facility and a vessel if the effective period of the declaration does not exceed

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 90 days at MARSEC level 1; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 30 days at MARSEC level 2.

Subsection.Text: If a declaration of security is required under subsection (1) between a vessel and the operator of a lock in the St. Lawrence Seaway, it shall be completed on its entry into the first lock and remain in effect until the vessel exits the St. Lawrence Seaway at the St. Lambert Lock or the Welland Canal at Port Colborne.

Heading.TitleText: Requirements for Persons Providing Security Assessment Information

Section.Text: The persons who provide security assessment information shall have, collectively, the competence to evaluate the security of the marine facility, including knowledge in the following areas:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: current security threats and patterns;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the detection and recognition of weapons, explosives and incendiaries and other dangerous substances and devices;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the recognition of the characteristics and behavioural patterns of persons who are likely to threaten security;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: techniques that might be used to violate security procedures or to circumvent security procedures, equipment or systems;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: methods used to cause a security incident;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the effects of dangerous substances and devices on structures and essential services;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: marine facility and vessel interface business practices;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: emergency preparedness and response and contingency planning;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: physical security requirements;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: radio and telecommunications systems, including computer systems and networks;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: marine or civil engineering; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: marine facility and vessel operations.

Subsection.Text: Security assessment information in respect of a marine facility

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall be in English or French;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shall be based on background information, the completion of an on-site survey and an analysis of that information and survey;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: shall identify and evaluate

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the physical aspects of the marine facility that are the most important to protect and the means for protecting the personnel,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: possible threats to the marine facility and the likelihood of their occurrence, in order to establish and prioritize security procedures and countermeasures, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the vulnerabilities, including human factors, in the security of the marine facility; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: may cover more than one marine facility.

Subsection.Text: Security assessment information shall consist of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the general layout of the marine facility, including the location of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: active and inactive access points to the marine facility,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: security doors, barriers, and lighting,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: restricted areas,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: emergency and stand-by equipment available to maintain essential services,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: storage areas for maintenance equipment, ships’ stores, cargo and unaccompanied baggage,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: escape and evacuation routes and assembly stations, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: existing security and safety equipment for the protection of personnel and visitors;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: changes in the tide that might have an impact on the vulnerability or security of the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a list of the emergency and stand-by equipment available to maintain essential services;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the number of marine facility personnel, the security tasks of persons with security responsibilities and the training requirements and procedures of the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a list of existing security and safety equipment for the protection of marine facility personnel and visitors;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: escape and evacuation routes and assembly stations that have to be maintained to ensure the orderly and safe emergency evacuation of the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the results of security audits; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: security procedures in effect, including inspection and control procedures, identification systems, surveillance and monitoring equipment, personnel identification documents and communication, alarm, lighting, access control and other appropriate systems.

Section.Text: The Minister shall conduct the marine facility security assessment, which addresses the following elements in respect of the marine facility, as applicable:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the physical security;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the structural integrity;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: personnel protection systems;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: operational procedures that might impact on security;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: its radio and telecommunications systems, including computer systems and networks;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: relevant transportation support infrastructure;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: utilities; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: other elements that might, if damaged or used illicitly, pose a risk to people, property or operations at the marine facility.

Heading.TitleText: Matters to be Taken into Account in Security Assessments

Section.Text: A marine facility security assessment shall take into account potential threats and the following types of security incidents:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: damage to, or destruction of, the marine facility or a vessel by explosive devices, arson, sabotage or vandalism;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: tampering with essential equipment or systems, ships’ stores or cargo of the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: unauthorized access to the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the smuggling onto the marine facility of weapons or equipment, including weapons of mass destruction;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: use of the marine facility itself as a weapon or as a means to cause damage or destruction;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: nuclear, biological, radiological, explosive or chemical attacks on the shoreside support system of the marine facility or on a vessel interfacing with the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the seizure of the marine facility or the seizure or hijacking of an interfacing vessel or persons on board; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: use of the marine facility or its equipment by persons intending to cause a security incident.

Section.Text: The operator of a marine facility shall ensure that an on-site survey of the marine facility is conducted. The survey shall examine and evaluate current protective procedures and operations to verify or collect security assessment information.

Subsection.Text: A marine facility security assessment shall include a vulnerability assessment undertaken in consultation with the operator of the marine facility to determine the following so as to produce an overall assessment of the level of risk for which security procedures have to be developed:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any particular aspect of the marine facility, including vessel traffic in the vicinity, that might make it a target of an attack;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the potential consequences of an attack on or at the marine facility in terms of loss of life, damage to property and economic disruption, including the disruption of marine transport systems;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the capability and intent of those likely to mount an attack; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the potential types of attack.

Subsection.Text: The vulnerability assessment shall include a consideration of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: current security procedures, including identification systems;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: methods and points of access to the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the procedures to protect radio and telecommunications equipment, including computer systems and networks;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any conflicting policies between safety and security procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any enforcement or personnel constraints;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: methods of monitoring restricted areas and other areas that have restricted access to ensure that only authorized persons have access;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: areas adjacent to the marine facility that might be exploited during or for an attack;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: current security procedures relating to utilities and other services;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: any deficiencies identified during training or drills;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: any deficiencies identified during daily operations or following incidents or alerts, reports of security concerns, the application of control measures or audits; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the structural integrity of the marine facility.

Section.Text: A marine facility security plan

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall be based on the findings of the marine facility security assessment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shall be in English or French;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: shall be submitted to the Minister for approval;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: is valid for a period determined by the Minister, which shall not exceed five years after the date of the Minister’s approval; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: may cover more than one marine facility if they share similarities in physical characteristics, location and operations.

Section.Text: A marine facility security plan shall address each vulnerability identified in the marine facility security assessment and include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the organization of the marine facility in terms of security, including the tasks of personnel who have security responsibilities;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the operator and the name and position of the marine facility security officer, including information on how they may be contacted at any time;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the identification of restricted areas and any security procedures, equipment and systems for those areas;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the procedures for and the frequency of drills and exercises;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a description of procedures for the following:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: ensuring the security of information in the marine facility security plan and keeping the records referred to in section 312,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: maintaining security and communication systems and equipment,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: identifying and correcting security equipment or systems failures or malfunctions,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: communications,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: responding to changes in the MARSEC level,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: interfacing with vessels at each MARSEC level,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: declarations of security,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: preventing unauthorized weapons, explosives, incendiaries or other dangerous substances or devices from entering the marine facility,

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: reporting security threats, security breaches and security incidents to the appropriate law enforcement agencies, the Minister and, if applicable, the port administration,

Subparagraph.Label: (x)
Subparagraph.Text: securing non-critical operations in order to focus response on critical operations, and

Subparagraph.Label: (xi)
Subparagraph.Text: periodically reviewing, updating and auditing the marine facility security plan;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a description of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: security procedures, equipment and systems for access control,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: security procedures for the delivery of ships’ stores and bunkers,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: security procedures, equipment and systems for monitoring the marine facility and surrounding area, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: procedures for security threats, security breaches and security incidents, including procedures for the evacuation of the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the rate at which inspections of the marine facility are conducted; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the identification of positions for which a transportation security clearance is required.

Heading.TitleText: MARSEC Level Coordination and Implementation of Security Procedures

Subsection.Text: The marine facility security plan shall contain security procedures for ensuring that, when the operator of the marine facility is notified of an increase in the MARSEC level,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the marine facility complies with the required additional security procedures within 12 hours after the notification;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a report indicating compliance or noncompliance with the MARSEC level is made to the Minister; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the vessels interfacing with the marine facility and the vessels scheduled to arrive at the marine facility within 96 hours after the MARSEC level is increased are notified of the new MARSEC level and the declaration of security is revised accordingly.

Subsection.Text: The marine facility security plan shall contain security procedures to ensure that, when notified of an increase in the MARSEC level, the marine facility security officer informs all marine facility personnel of identified security threats, emphasizes reporting procedures and stresses the need for increased vigilance.
For MARSEC levels 2 and 3, the marine facility security plan shall contain procedures for ensuring that the operator of the marine facility evaluates the need for additional security procedures.
A marine facility security plan shall contain security procedures, as appropriate to the facility’s operations, to control access to the marine facility at each MARSEC level and to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: deter the unauthorized entry of weapons, explosives and incendiaries, including any device that could be used to damage or destroy marine facilities or vessels or harm individuals;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: secure any weapons, explosives, incendiaries or other dangerous substances and devices that are authorized by the operator to be at the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: identify the locations at which restrictions or prohibitions preventing unauthorized access are to be applied for each MARSEC level and that each location allowing access to the marine facility is addressed;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: identify the types of restrictions or prohibitions to be applied and the means of enforcing them;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: establish the means of identification required to allow persons and vehicles to have access to or to remain in the marine facility without challenge;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
