Paragraph.Text: identify the locations at which the authorized screening of persons and goods, including vehicles, is to be conducted, and to ensure that these locations are covered to enable continuous screenings regardless of weather conditions; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: facilitate shore leave for vessel personnel or crew change.

Subsection.Text: The plan shall contain security procedures for verification of the identity of marine facility personnel and other persons seeking access to the marine facility that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: allow identification of authorized persons at each MARSEC level;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: are coordinated, to the extent practicable, with the identification systems of vessels that interface with the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: are updated regularly; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: allow temporary or continuing access to the marine facility by marine facility personnel, vessel personnel and other authorized persons, through the use of a badge or other means of verifying their identity.

Subsection.Text: The plan shall set out the frequency of application of access controls, particularly if they are to be applied on a random or occasional basis.

Section.Text: For MARSEC level 1, the security procedures for access control shall include, as appropriate to the facility’s operations,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: verifying the identity of every person seeking to enter a controlled access area and the reasons for which they seek entry by confirming at least one of the following:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: joining instructions,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: passenger tickets,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: boarding passes,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: work orders or marine surveyor orders,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: government identification,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: restricted area passes,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: access passes or other identification issued by the marine facility or, if applicable, passes issued by the port administration, or

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: visitor badges issued in accordance with an identification system;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: authorized screening, at the rate specified in the marine facility security plan, of persons and goods, including vehicles, for weapons, explosives or incendiaries;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: denying or revoking access to a marine facility by persons who are unable or unwilling, at the request of marine facility personnel, to establish their identity or account for their presence at the marine facility and recording details of the denials and revocations;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: determining the appropriate access controls for restricted areas;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: identifying access points that must be secured or attended to deter unauthorized access; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: deterring unauthorized access to the marine facility and to restricted areas.

Section.Text: For MARSEC level 2, the additional security procedures for access control shall include, as appropriate to the facility’s operations,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: increasing the frequency and detail of the authorized screening of persons and goods, including vehicles, entering the marine facility, for weapons, explosives and incendiaries;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: X-ray screening of all unaccompanied baggage for weapons, explosives and incendiaries;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: assigning additional personnel to guard access points and to patrol the perimeter of the marine facility to deter unauthorized access;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: limiting the number of access points to the marine facility by closing and securing some access points and providing physical barriers to impede movement through the remaining access points;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: denying or revoking access by persons who are unable to provide a verifiable justification for seeking access to the marine facility; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: coordinating with the Minister, the appropriate law enforcement agencies and, if the marine facility is in a port, the port administration for the deterrence of waterside access to the marine facility, including using waterborne patrols to enhance security around the marine facility and any vessels located there.

Section.Text: For MARSEC level 3, the additional security procedures for access control shall include, as appropriate to the facility’s operations,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: conducting the authorized screening of all persons and goods, including vehicles, for weapons, explosives and incendiaries;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of unaccompanied baggage,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: conducting authorized screening more extensively for weapons, explosives and incendiaries, for example, by X-raying from two or more angles,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: restricting or suspending the handling of it, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: refusing to accept it;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: cooperating with emergency response personnel and other marine facilities;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: granting access only to those responding to a security incident or security threat;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: suspending access to the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: suspending cargo operations;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: evacuating the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: restricting pedestrian or vehicular movement on the grounds of the marine facility; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: increasing monitoring at the marine facility.

Subsection.Text: A marine facility security plan shall designate restricted areas, as appropriate to the facility’s operations, in order to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prevent or deter unauthorized access;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: protect the marine facility, including security and surveillance equipment and systems, and persons authorized to be at the facility;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: protect vessels interfacing with the marine facility; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: protect ships’ stores from tampering.

Subsection.Text: The plan shall contain security procedures to ensure that notices are posted in compliance with section 21 of the Act.
Restricted areas shall be established for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: land areas adjacent to vessels interfacing with the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: areas in which security-sensitive information is kept, including cargo documentation;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: areas containing the central controls for security and surveillance equipment and systems and areas that contain the central lighting system controls;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: areas containing the critical infrastructure of the marine facility, such as

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: water supplies,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: telecommunications,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: electrical systems, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: access points for ventilation and air-conditioning systems;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: manufacturing or processing areas and control rooms;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: locations in the marine facility where it is reasonable to restrict access by vehicles and persons;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: areas designated for loading, unloading or storage of cargo and ships’ stores; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: areas containing certain dangerous cargoes.

Subsection.Text: The following areas shall be established as restricted area two:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: areas in the marine facilities set out in Part 1 of Schedule 1 that contain the central controls for security and surveillance equipment and systems and areas that contain the central lighting system controls; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: areas that are designated for the loading or unloading of cargo and ships’ stores at the cruise ship terminals set out in Part 1 of Schedule 1 and land areas adjacent to vessels interfacing with those cruise ship terminals.

Section.Text: A marine facility security plan shall contain security procedures, as appropriate to the facility’s operations, for restricted areas at each MARSEC level for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: identifying the marine facility personnel and other persons who are authorized to have access;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: determining the conditions under which access may take place including procedures for escorting persons who do not have restricted area passes;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: establishing the times during which access restrictions apply; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: ensuring that notices are posted in compliance with section 21 of the Act.

Subsection.Text: For MARSEC level 1, a marine facility security plan shall contain security procedures, as appropriate to the facility’s operations, to prevent unauthorized access or activities in restricted areas that include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: restricting access to authorized personnel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: securing all access points not actively used and providing physical barriers to impede movement through the remaining access points;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: controlling access to restricted areas;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: examining the identification and authorization of persons and vehicles seeking entry;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: patrolling or monitoring the perimeter of restricted areas;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: using security personnel, automatic intrusion detection devices, surveillance equipment or surveillance systems to detect unauthorized entry into or movement in restricted areas;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: directing the parking, loading and unloading of vehicles in restricted areas;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: controlling the movement and storage of cargo and ships’ stores;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: designating restricted areas for performing inspections of cargo and ships’ stores that are awaiting loading; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: designating temporary restricted areas to accommodate marine facility operations, including restricted areas for segregating unaccompanied baggage that has undergone authorized screening by a vessel operator.

Subsection.Text: The marine facility security plan shall include a requirement that, if a temporary restricted area is designated, a security sweep of it shall be conducted both before and after it is designated.

Section.Text: For MARSEC level 2, additional security procedures for restricted areas shall include, as appropriate to the facility’s operations,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: increasing the intensity and frequency of monitoring and access control of restricted areas;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: enhancing the effectiveness of the physical barriers surrounding restricted areas, by the use of patrols or automatic intrusion detection devices;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: reducing the number of access points to restricted areas and enhancing the controls applied at the remaining access points;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: restricting the parking of vehicles adjacent to vessels;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: reducing access to the restricted areas and movements and storage in them;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: using surveillance equipment that records and monitors continuously;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: increasing the number and frequency of patrols, including the use of waterborne patrols; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: establishing and restricting access to areas adjacent to restricted areas.

Section.Text: For MARSEC level 3, the additional security procedures for restricted areas shall include, as appropriate to the facility’s operations,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: designating additional restricted areas;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: prohibiting access to restricted areas; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: searching restricted areas as part of a security sweep of all or part of the marine facility.

Section.Text: A marine facility security plan shall contain security procedures, as appropriate to the facility’s operations, for cargo handling for each MARSEC level for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: deterring tampering and detecting evidence of it;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: preventing cargo that is not meant for carriage from being accepted or stored at the marine facility without the consent of the operator of the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: identifying cargo that is accepted for loading onto vessels interfacing with the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: controlling inventory at access points to the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: identifying cargo that is accepted for temporary storage in a restricted area while awaiting loading or pick up;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: releasing cargo only to the carrier specified in the cargo documentation;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: coordinating with shippers and other persons responsible for cargo;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: creating, updating, and maintaining a continuous inventory of certain dangerous cargoes, from receipt to delivery in the marine facility, that sets out the location in which they are stored; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the examination of the documentation of cargo entering the marine facility.

Section.Text: For MARSEC level 1, the security procedures for cargo handling shall include, as appropriate to the facility’s operations,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: verifying that cargo, containers and cargo transport units entering the marine facility match the invoice or other cargo documentation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: routinely inspecting cargo, containers, cargo transport units and cargo storage areas in the marine facility before and during cargo handling operations to detect evidence of tampering, unless it is unsafe to do so;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: examining documents for vehicles entering the marine facility; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: examining seals and other methods used to detect evidence of tampering when cargo, containers or cargo transport units enter the marine facility or are stored there.

Section.Text: For MARSEC level 2, the additional security procedures for cargo handling shall include, as appropriate to the facility’s operations,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: authorized screening of cargo, containers, and cargo transport units in or about to enter the marine facility and cargo storage areas for weapons, explosives and incendiaries;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: intensifying inspections to ensure that only documented cargo enters the marine facility, is temporarily stored there and is then loaded on board a vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: authorized screening of vehicles for weapons, explosives and incendiaries;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: increasing the frequency and detail of examinations of seals and other methods used to prevent tampering;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: segregating inbound cargo, outbound cargo and ships’ stores;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: increasing the frequency and intensity of visual and physical inspections; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: limiting the number of locations where certain dangerous cargoes are stored.

Section.Text: For MARSEC level 3, the additional security procedures for cargo handling shall include, as appropriate to the facility’s operations,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: restricting or suspending cargo movements or operations in all or part of the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: cooperating with responders and vessels; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: confirming the inventory and location of certain dangerous cargoes in the marine facility.

Heading.TitleText: Security Procedures for Delivery of Ships’ Stores and Bunkers

Section.Text: A marine facility security plan shall contain security procedures, as appropriate to the facility’s operations, for the delivery of ships’ stores and bunkers for each MARSEC level for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: inspecting ships’ stores for package integrity;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: preventing them from being accepted without inspection; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: preventing tampering.

Section.Text: For MARSEC level 1, the security procedures for ships’ stores and bunkers shall include, as appropriate to the facility’s operations,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: coordinating with vessel operators that are inspecting ships’ stores;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: requiring advance notification of the delivery of ships’ stores or bunkers, including a list of stores or bunkers, and driver and vehicle registration information in respect of the delivery vehicle;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: inspecting delivery vehicles at the rate specified in the marine facility security plan; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: controlling the delivery vehicles in the marine facility.

Section.Text: For MARSEC level 2, the additional security procedures for ships’ stores and bunkers shall include, as appropriate to the facility’s operations,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: coordinating with vessel operators that are inspecting ships’ stores more intensively;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: authorized screening of delivery vehicles for weapons, explosives and incendiaries at the rate specified in the marine facility security plan;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: verifying that ships’ stores and bunkers, before they enter the marine facility, match the invoice or other documentation;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: escorting delivery vehicles in the marine facility; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: restricting or prohibiting the entry of ships’ stores and bunkers that will not leave the marine facility within the period of time set out in the invoice or other documentation.

Section.Text: For MARSEC level 3, the additional security procedures for the delivery of ships’ stores and bunkers shall include, as appropriate to the facility’s operations,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: authorized screening of all delivery vehicles for weapons, explosives and incendiaries;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: restricting or suspending the delivery of ships’ stores and bunkers; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: refusing to accept ships’ stores and bunkers in the marine facility.

Subsection.Text: A marine facility security plan shall contain, as appropriate to the facility’s operations, security procedures for each MARSEC level for the continuous monitoring of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the marine facility and its approaches on land and water;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: restricted areas in the marine facility; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: vessels interfacing with the marine facility.

Subsection.Text: The plan may provide that the monitoring may be effected by any combination of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: lighting;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: security guards, on foot or in vehicles, and waterborne patrols; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: automatic intrusion-detection devices and surveillance equipment.

Subsection.Text: The following shall be ensured when establishing the appropriate level and location of lighting:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: marine facility personnel are able to detect activities at the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the lighting facilitates the identification of persons at access points; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the lighting can be provided through coordination with the port administration and vessels.

Subsection.Text: The plan shall provide that monitoring equipment

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if it is an automatic intrusion-detection device, activates an audible or visual alarm, or both, at a location that is continuously attended or monitored;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is able to function continuously, including during periods of adverse weather or power disruption;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: monitors access and movements adjacent to vessels interfacing with the marine facility; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: limits lighting effects, such as glare, and their impact on safety, navigation and other security activities.

Section.Text: For MARSEC level 1, the security procedures shall provide, as appropriate to the facility’s operations, for monitoring at all times.
For MARSEC level 2, the additional security procedures for monitoring shall include, as appropriate to the facility’s operations,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: increasing the coverage and intensity of lighting and surveillance equipment, including the provision of additional lighting and surveillance;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: increasing the frequency of foot, vehicle or waterborne patrols; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: assigning additional security personnel to monitor and patrol.

Section.Text: For MARSEC level 3, the additional security procedures for monitoring shall include, as appropriate to the facility’s operations,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: switching on all lighting in, or illuminating the vicinity of, the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: switching on all surveillance equipment capable of recording activities in or adjacent to the marine facility; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: maximizing the length of time that surveillance equipment can continue to record.

Heading.TitleText: Security Threats, Security Breaches and Security Incidents

Section.Text: At each MARSEC level, the marine security plan shall contain procedures, as appropriate to the facility’s operations, for the marine facility security officer and persons who have security responsibilities with respect to the facility to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: respond to security threats, security breaches and security incidents and maintain critical marine facility and interface operations, including by

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: prohibiting entry into the affected area,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: denying access to the marine facility, except to persons responding to the threat, breach or incident,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: implementing MARSEC level 3 security procedures throughout the marine facility,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: stopping cargo-handling operations, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: notifying shoreside authorities or vessels of the threat or incident;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: evacuate the marine facility in case of security threats and security incidents;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: report any security threats, security breaches or security incidents to the Minister without undue delay;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: brief marine facility personnel on potential threats to security and the need for vigilance and their assistance in reporting suspicious persons, objects or activities; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: secure non-critical operations in order to focus response on critical operations.

Heading.TitleText: Additional Passenger Facility and Ferry Facility Requirements

Subsection.Text: For MARSEC level 1, the marine facility security plan in respect of a passenger facility or a ferry facility shall contain security procedures additional to those required in sections 324 to 345 for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in a marine facility with no designated public access area, establishing separate areas to segregate persons and goods, including vehicles, that have not been screened from those that have;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in a marine facility with a designated public access area, providing sufficient security personnel to monitor all persons in the area and to conduct authorized screening of persons and goods;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: authorized screening of vehicles to be loaded on board a vessel for weapons, explosives and incendiaries before loading;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: authorized screening of all unaccompanied vehicles to be loaded on board a vessel for weapons, explosives and incendiaries before loading; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: denying passenger access to restricted areas unless the restricted areas are monitored by marine facility security personnel.

Subsection.Text: For MARSEC level 2, the marine facility security plan in respect of a passenger facility or ferry facility that has no designated public access area shall contain additional security procedures for the authorized screening of passengers and goods, including vehicles, before they board or are loaded on board a vessel.
For MARSEC level 3, the marine facility security plan of a passenger facility or ferry facility with no designated public access area shall contain additional security procedures for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: verifying the identity of all persons and conducting authorized screening of them for weapons, explosives and incendiaries;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: conducting authorized screening of all goods, including vehicles, for weapons, explosives and incendiaries; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: assigning additional security personnel and patrols.

Heading.TitleText: Additional Requirements for Cruise Ship Terminals

Section.Text: For each MARSEC level, the marine facility security plan in respect of a cruise ship terminal shall contain security procedures additional to those required in sections 324 to 345 for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: verifying the identity of all persons seeking to enter a controlled access area of the cruise ship terminal by, for example, confirming the reason for boarding or examining joining instructions, passenger tickets, boarding passes, government identification, visitor badges or work orders;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: assisting the operator of a vessel to coordinate the authorized screening of all persons and goods, including vehicles, for weapons, explosives and incendiaries;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: designating holding, waiting and embarkation areas to segregate persons and baggage that have been screened and are awaiting embarkation from those that have not been screened;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: providing additional security personnel to designated holding, waiting, and embarkation areas; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: denying passenger access to restricted areas.

Subsection.Text: For each MARSEC level, the marine facility security plan in respect of a CDC facility shall contain security procedures additional to those required in sections 324 to 345 for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: except in the case of prearranged cargo deliveries, escorting all persons who are not personnel of the CDC facility at all times while they are at the CDC facility if they do not provide access identification;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: controlling the parking and loading and unloading of vehicles;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: requiring security personnel to record or report their presence at key points during their patrols;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: conducting a security sweep of unmanned or unmonitored waterfront areas for dangerous substances and devices before a vessel’s arrival; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: providing an alternative or independent power source for security and communication systems.

Subsection.Text: For MARSEC level 2, the additional security procedures shall include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: releasing cargo only in the presence of the marine facility security officer; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: continuously guarding or patrolling restricted areas.

Subsection.Text: For MARSEC level 3, the marine facility security plan shall contain additional security procedures to ensure that the CDC facility is continuously guarded and the restricted areas are patrolled.

An audit of a marine facility security plan shall take into account the most recent marine facility security assessment and determine whether there are any deficiencies or changes in security threats, procedures, responsibilities of personnel, operations or operator that require amendments to be made to the plan.
An audit is conducted

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: annually, effective on the day on which the plan is approved; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: whenever there is a new operator of the marine facility, a change in operations or location or modifications to the marine facility that could affect its security.

Subsection.Text: Persons conducting an audit shall have knowledge of the methods of conducting audits and inspections and of access control and monitoring techniques and, if possible, be independent of the activities being audited.

If the results of an audit require an amendment to be made to the marine facility security assessment or plan, the marine facility security officer shall submit an amendment to the Minister for approval within 30 days after completion of the audit.
The operator of a marine facility may submit to the Minister other amendments to the approved marine facility security plan. They shall be submitted at least 30 days before they are to take effect.

The operator of a marine facility shall, within 60 days after the day on which the Minister informs the operator in writing that the marine facility security plan no longer meets the requirements to remain approved, ensure that amendments are submitted to the Minister for approval.

If amendments are required under subsection (4) or (6) and they are not submitted or the amended plan is not approved, the plan ceases to be valid on the day on which the operator of the marine facility receives notification that the plan is no longer valid.
The marine facility security officer shall attach to the plan an approval document issued under subsection 352(1).

If the Minister is satisfied that a marine facility security plan meets the requirements of this Part, the Minister shall approve the plan and issue a letter of approval certifying that the plan meets the requirements of this Part, unless approving the plan is not in the public interest and is likely to adversely affect marine transportation security.

Subject to subsection 351(7), a plan is valid for the period fixed by the Minister, not exceeding five years after the day on which it is approved by the Minister. In fixing the period, the Minister shall consider the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the marine facility’s operations and the industry in which it operates;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the operator’s security record;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the marine facility’s security record;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the complexity of the marine facility security plan and the details of its procedures; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the findings of the marine facility security assessment.

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall issue, in English or French, an interim statement of compliance in respect of a marine facility if the marine facility security plan has been approved but a security inspector has not yet conducted an inspection under section 23 of the Act to ensure compliance with the requirements of this Part.

The interim statement of compliance is valid until the expiry of six months after the day on which it is issued or until a statement of compliance is issued under subsection (5), whichever comes first.

If the Minister is satisfied, on the basis of an inspection conducted under section 23 of the Act, that the requirements of this Part have been met, the Minister shall issue, in English or French, a statement of compliance in respect of the marine facility.
The interim statement of compliance and the statement of compliance are valid while the approved security plan in respect of the marine facility is valid.

Section.Text: No person shall operate a marine facility, except an occasional-use marine facility, without a valid interim statement of compliance issued under subsection 352(3) or a valid statement of compliance issued under subsection 352(5).
The operator of an occasional-use marine facility shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: establish an administrative and organizational structure for security at the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide every person who has responsibilities under this Part with the support needed to fulfil their responsibilities;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: designate in writing an occasional-use marine facility security officer by name or by a position other than the position for which the designation is being made;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the implementation of the marine facility security procedures is coordinated with vessels interfacing with the marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: coordinate, with the master of a vessel and, if applicable, the port security officer, shore leave for vessel personnel or crew change, as well as access through the marine facility of visitors to vessels, including representatives of seafarers’ welfare and labour organizations;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: provide information respecting the security of the facility to those persons who need it to comply with these Regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: clearly mark with signs each restricted area at the marine facility.

Subsection.Text: An occasional-use marine facility security officer may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: act in that capacity for more than one occasional-use marine facility if they are able to fulfil the responsibilities for each occasional-use marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have other responsibilities within the operator’s organization if they are able to fulfil their responsibilities; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: delegate tasks required by section 358.

Subsection.Text: An occasional-use marine facility security officer remains responsible for the performance of the tasks they delegate.

Section.Text: An occasional-use marine facility security officer shall have, by training or job experience, knowledge and competence that is relevant to the industry in which the marine facility operates and is in the following areas:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the administrative and organizational structure for security at the occasional-use marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the operations and operating conditions of the occasional-use marine facility and vessels;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the security procedures of the occasional-use marine facility, vessels and port, including the meaning and the requirements of the different MARSEC levels;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: emergency preparedness and response and contingency planning;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: security equipment and systems and their operational limitations;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: relevant international conventions, codes, standards and recommendations;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: relevant legislation, regulations and security measures, rules and procedures; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the responsibilities and functions of municipal, provincial and federal law enforcement agencies.

Section.Text: An occasional-use marine facility security officer shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ensure security awareness and vigilance at the occasional-use marine facility, including awareness of changes in the MARSEC level and other circumstances that might affect work conditions there;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that appropriate security training is provided to personnel at the occasional-use marine facility in accordance with this Part;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: report security incidents to the appropriate law enforcement agencies and the Minister as soon as possible after they occur so that an investigation can be conducted;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: coordinate the signing and implementation of the declaration of security between the occasional-use marine facility and interfacing vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: shall, in the case of an interface with a vessel to which Part 2 applies, ensure that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: security sweeps are performed before and after the interface in order to confirm the absence of security threats, dangerous substances or devices, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: implement any temporary security procedures that are required during the interface; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: keep records of security sweeps and declarations of security in respect of the occasional-use marine facility and send a copy of each declaration of security to the Minister.

Subsection.Text: Security procedures shall be established for an occasional-use marine facility. The security procedures shall include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the organization of the occasional-use marine facility in terms of security, including the tasks of marine facility personnel with security responsibilities;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the operator and the name and position of the occasional-use marine facility security officer, including information on how they may be contacted at any time;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a description of procedures for:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: responding to changes in the MARSEC level,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: interfacing, at each MARSEC level, with vessels to which Part 2 applies,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: coordinating, with the master of a vessel and, if applicable, the port security officer, shore leave for vessel personnel or crew change, as well as access to the vessel by visitors passing through the occasional-use marine facility,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: reporting security incidents to the appropriate law enforcement agencies, the Minister and, if applicable, the port administration,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: meeting the requirements respecting declarations of security,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: implementing any temporary security procedures that are required during an interface,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: keeping the records referred to in paragraph 358(f),

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: as appropriate to the occasional-use marine facility’s operations, briefing marine facility personnel on potential threats to security and on the need for vigilance and for their assistance in reporting suspicious persons, objects or activities, at each MARSEC level, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: as appropriate to the occasional-use marine facility’s operations, performing the security sweeps required by paragraph 358(e).

Subsection.Text: The security procedures established for an occasional-use marine facility shall also include procedures, as appropriate to the marine facility’s operations, to control access to the marine facility at each MARSEC level and to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: deter the unauthorized entry of weapons, explosives and incendiaries, including any device that could be used to damage or destroy marine facilities or vessels or harm individuals;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: secure any weapons, explosives, incendiaries or other dangerous substances and devices that are authorized by the operator to be at the occasional-use marine facility;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: identify the locations at which restrictions or prohibitions to prevent unauthorized access are to be applied for each MARSEC level and specify that each location allowing access to the occasional-use marine facility is to be addressed;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: identify the types of restrictions or prohibitions to be applied and the means of applying them;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: establish the means of identification required to allow persons and vehicles to have access to or remain in the occasional-use marine facility without challenge; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: identify the locations at which the authorized screening of persons and goods, including vehicles, is to be conducted, and ensure that these locations are covered in order to enable continuous screening regardless of weather conditions.

Subsection.Text: If the Minister is satisfied that the security procedures for an occasional-use marine facility meet the requirements of section 359, the Minister shall approve the security procedures and issue a letter of compliance certifying that they meet the requirements of this Part, unless approving the security procedures is not in the public interest and is likely to adversely affect marine transportation security.

Security procedures are valid for the period fixed by the Minister, which shall not exceed five years after the day on which they are approved by the Minister. In fixing the period, the Minister shall consider the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the marine facility’s operations and the industry in which it operates;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the operator’s security record;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the marine facility’s security record; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the complexity of the security procedures of the marine facility and the details of those procedures.

Section.Text: No person shall operate an occasional-use marine facility without a valid letter of compliance issued under subsection 360(1).
A port administration shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: establish, convene, and direct a port security committee;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: designate in writing, by name, a port security officer who will chair the port security committee;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: conduct an on-site survey and submit to the Minister the security assessment information respecting the port;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: provide the Minister with the information that is necessary to conduct a vulnerability assessment;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: submit a port security plan, and any amendment, to the Minister for approval;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: ensure the coordination of marine transportation security in consultation with the port security committee;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that the requirements of sections 363 to 375, 384 to 386 and 392, subsection 393(2) and section 394 are fulfilled;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: operate the port in accordance with the port security plan; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: clearly mark with signs each restricted area at the port.

Heading.TitleText: Responsibilities of the Port Security Officer

Section.Text: The port security officer shall develop a port security plan with the marine facility security officers at the port and in consultation with representatives of federal departments and agencies, provincial and municipal governments, appropriate law enforcement agencies, emergency response providers, employers and labour at the port.

Heading.TitleText: Responsibilities of the Port Security Committee

Subsection.Text: The port security committee shall coordinate marine transportation security, which may include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the identification of critical infrastructure and operations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the identification of risks, threats, vulnerabilities and consequences;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the determination of mitigation strategies and implementation methods; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the establishment of a process to continually evaluate marine transportation security.

Subsection.Text: The port security committee shall meet at least once a year for the purpose of reviewing its responsibilities that result from the application of subsection (1) and determining on that basis whether any modifications are required to the port security plan.

Heading.TitleText: Composition of the Port Security Committee

Section.Text: The chair of the port security committee may appoint other committee members from organizations concerned or affected by the security of the port including representatives of marine facilities, labour and municipal and provincial governments.
Security assessment information in respect of a port shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be in English or French;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be based on background information, the completion of an on-site survey and an analysis of that information and survey;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: identify and evaluate

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the physical aspects of the port that are the most important to protect and the means for protecting the personnel,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: possible threats to the port, and the likelihood of their occurrence, in order to establish security procedures and countermeasures and their order of priority, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the vulnerabilities, including human factors, in the security of the port;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: be protected from unauthorized access or disclosure; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: if stored in electronic format, have procedures to prevent its unauthorized deletion, destruction or amendment.

Heading.TitleText: Requirements for Persons Providing Port Security Assessment Information

Section.Text: The persons who provide port security assessment information shall have, collectively, the competence to evaluate the security of the port, including knowledge in the following areas:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: current security threats and patterns;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the detection and recognition of weapons, explosives and incendiaries and other dangerous substances and devices;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the recognition of the characteristics and behavioural patterns of persons who are likely to threaten security;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: techniques that might be used to violate security procedures or to circumvent security procedures, equipment or systems;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: methods used to cause a security incident;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the effects of dangerous substances and devices on structures and essential services;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: port security, marine facility and vessel security requirements;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: marine facility and vessel interface business practices;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: emergency preparedness and response and contingency planning;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: physical security requirements;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: radio and telecommunications systems, including computer systems and networks;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: marine or civil engineering; and

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: marine facility and vessel operations.

Section.Text: Port security assessment information shall consist of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the general layout of the port, including the location of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: active and inactive access points to the port,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: security doors, barriers, and lighting,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: restricted areas,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: emergency and stand-by equipment available to maintain essential services,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: storage areas for maintenance equipment, unaccompanied baggage, ships’ stores and cargo,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: escape and evacuation routes and assembly stations, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: existing security and safety equipment for the protection of personnel and visitors;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: changes in the tide that might have an impact on the vulnerability or security of the port;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a list of the emergency and stand-by equipment available to maintain essential services;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: for each marine facility in the port, the number of personnel and the security tasks of persons with security responsibilities;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: existing security and safety equipment for the protection of personnel and visitors at the port;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: escape and evacuation routes and assembly stations that have to be maintained to ensure the orderly and safe emergency evacuation of the port;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the results of security audits; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: security procedures in effect, including inspection and access control procedures, identification systems, surveillance and monitoring equipment, personnel identification documents and communication, alarm, lighting and other appropriate systems.

Section.Text: The Minister shall conduct a port security assessment that addresses the following elements in respect of the port, as applicable:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the physical security;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the structural integrity;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: personnel protection systems;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: operational procedures that might impact on security;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the radio and telecommunications systems, including computer systems and networks;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the relevant transportation support infrastructure;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: utilities;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: response organizations; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: other elements that might, if damaged or used illicitly, pose a risk to persons, property or operations at the port.

Section.Text: The on-site survey shall examine and evaluate current protective procedures and operations to verify or collect port security assessment information.

Subsection.Text: A port security assessment shall include a vulnerability assessment undertaken in consultation with the operators of marine facilities in the port and representatives of labour to determine the following so as to produce an overall assessment of the level of risk against which security procedures have to be developed:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any particular aspect of the port, including vessel traffic in the vicinity, that could make it a target of an attack;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the possible consequences of an attack against the port in terms of loss of life, damage to property and economic disruption, including disruption to marine transport systems;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the capability and intent of persons likely to mount an attack; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the possible types of attack.

Subsection.Text: The vulnerability assessment shall include a consideration of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: current security procedures, including identification systems;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: methods and points of access to the port;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the procedures to protect radio and telecommunications equipment, including computer systems and networks;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any conflicting policies between safety and security procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any enforcement or personnel constraints;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: methods for monitoring restricted areas and other areas that have restricted access to ensure that only authorized persons have access;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: areas adjacent to the port that might be exploited during or for an attack;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: current security procedures relating to utilities and other services;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: any deficiencies identified during training or drills;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: any deficiencies identified during daily operations or following incidents or alerts, reports of security concerns, the application of control measures or audits; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the structural integrity of the port.

Section.Text: A port security plan

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall be based on the findings of the port security assessment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shall be in English or French;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: shall be protected from unauthorized access or disclosure;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: shall, if stored in electronic format, have procedures to prevent its unauthorized deletion, destruction or amendment; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: shall be submitted to the Minister for approval.

Subsection.Text: If the Minister is satisfied that a security plan meets the requirements of this Part, the Minister shall approve the security plan and issue a letter of approval certifying that the plan meets the requirements of this Part, unless approving the plan is not in the public interest and is likely to adversely affect marine transportation security.

The plan is valid for the period fixed by the Minister, which shall not exceed five years after the day on which it is approved by the Minister. In fixing the period, the Minister shall consider the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the port’s operations and the industry in which it operates;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the port administration’s security record; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the complexity of the port security plan and the details of its procedures.

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall issue, in English or French, an interim statement of compliance in respect of a port if the port security plan has been approved but a security inspector has not yet conducted an inspection under section 23 of the Act to ensure compliance with the requirements of this Part.

The interim statement of compliance is valid until the expiry of six months after the day on which it is issued or until a statement of compliance is issued under subsection (5), whichever comes first.

If the Minister is satisfied, on the basis of an inspection conducted under section 23 of the Act, that the requirements of this Part have been met, the Minister shall issue, in English or French, a statement of compliance in respect of the port.
The interim statement of compliance and the statement of compliance are valid while the approved security plan in respect of the port is valid.

Section.Text: No person shall operate a port without a valid interim statement of compliance issued under subsection 372.1(3) or a valid statement of compliance issued under subsection 372.1(5).
The port security plan shall address each vulnerability identified in the port security assessment and include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the organization of the port administration in terms of security, including the tasks of personnel who have security responsibilities;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the port administration and the name and position of the port security officer, including information on how they may be contacted at any time;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the identification of restricted areas and any security procedures, equipment or systems for those areas;

Paragraph.Label: (c.1)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a port set out in Part 2 or 3 of Schedule 1, the identification of those areas containing the central controls for security and surveillance equipment and systems and areas that contain the central lighting system controls as restricted area two;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a description of procedures for and frequency of exercises;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a description of procedures for the following:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: ensuring the security of information in the port security plan and keeping the records referred to in section 375,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: maintaining security and communication systems and equipment,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: identifying and correcting security equipment or systems failures or malfunctions,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: communications,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: responding to changes in the MARSEC level,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: preventing unauthorized weapons, explosives, incendiaries or other dangerous substances or devices from entering the marine facilities in the port,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: reporting security threats and security incidents to the appropriate law enforcement agencies and the Minister as soon as possible after they occur so that an investigation can be conducted,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: reporting security breaches to the Minister,

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: securing non-critical operations in order to focus response on critical operations, and

Subparagraph.Label: (x)
Subparagraph.Text: periodically reviewing, updating and auditing the port security plan;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a description of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: security procedures, equipment and systems for access control,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: security procedures for the delivery of ships’ stores and bunkers,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: security procedures, equipment and systems for monitoring the port and surrounding area, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: procedures for security threats, security breaches and security incidents, including procedures for the evacuation of the port;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the identification of positions for which a transportation security clearance is required; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the procedures to facilitate shore leave for vessel personnel or crew change.

Subsection.Text: Port security exercises

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall fully test the port security plan and include the substantial and active participation of personnel who have security responsibilities in the port;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: may include security personnel from vessels, other marine facilities, appropriate law enforcement agencies, the Minister and other competent authorities, depending on the scope and the nature of the exercises; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: shall test communication and notification procedures and elements of coordination, resource availability and response.

Subsection.Text: The port security exercises shall be conducted at least once every calendar year with no more than 18 months between them.
Exercises may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be full-scale or live;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be a tabletop simulation or seminar;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be combined with other appropriate exercises; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: be a combination of two or more of the elements set out in paragraphs (a) to (c).

Subsection.Text: The port security officer shall, in respect of the port, keep records of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: security training, including the date, the duration and description and the names of the participants;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: security drills and exercises, including the date and description, the names of the participating marine facilities and any best practices or lessons learned that might improve the port security plan;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: security threats, security breaches and security incidents, including the date, time, location and description, the response to them and the person to whom they were reported;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: changes in the MARSEC level, including the date, the time that notification was received and the time of compliance with the security requirements of the new level;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: maintenance, calibration and testing of equipment used in security, including the date and time of the activity and the equipment involved;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: internal audits and reviews of security activities;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: security assessment information;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the port security assessment and each periodic review of the port security assessment, including the date on which it was conducted and the findings of the review;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the port security plan and each periodic review of the port security plan, including the date on which it was conducted, the findings of the review and any amendments to the plan that are recommended;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: each amendment to the port security plan, including the date of its approval and implementation;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: a list of the persons in the port administration who have security responsibilities;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: an up-to-date list containing the names of screening officers; and

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: an up-to-date list, by name and position, of the holders of transportation security clearances.

Subsection.Text: Records respecting equipment that is not used exclusively for security may be kept separately from the records respecting equipment that is used exclusively for security if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the port security officer documents, in written or electronic form, their existence and location and the name of the person responsible for their maintenance; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: they are accessible to the port security officer.

Subsection.Text: The port security officer shall ensure that the records are kept for at least two years after the day on which they are made and make them available to the Minister on request.
The records shall be protected from unauthorized access or disclosure.
The records may be kept in electronic format if they are protected from deletion, destruction and revision.
No person shall disclose security information contained in the records, unless the disclosure is for the purpose of complying with these Regulations.
No person shall enter or remain in a restricted area unless they are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the holder of a restricted area pass issued under section 384 for that restricted area;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a person who does not ordinarily work at the marine facility or port and who is being escorted by a holder of a restricted area pass;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an inspector designated under subsection 22(1) of the Act who is on duty;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a member of one of the following groups who is on duty at a marine facility or on a vessel at a marine facility:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: any police force in Canada,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the Canadian Security Intelligence Service,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the Canadian Forces within the meaning of those words in Part II of the National Defence Act, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the Canada Border Services Agency;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a provider of emergency services who requires access to the area for the protection and preservation of life or property; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a member of the complement of the vessel in the performance of their duties and in compliance with the vessel security plan and the marine facility security plan.

Subsection.Text: A commercial truck driver who is required to enter a restricted area two at a marine facility or port as part of their commercial activities may enter and remain in the area to carry out the activities if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the driver holds a valid FAST/EXPRES card issued under the Free and Secure Trade (FAST) program by the Canada Border Services Agency or the U.S. Customs and Border Protection;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the operator of the marine facility or port administration informs the driver of all applicable procedures and requirements, as identified and approved in the marine facility security plan, and ensures that the driver meets the procedures and requirements; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the driver follows the procedures and requirements identified by the operator of the marine facility or port administration.

Subsection.Text: A passenger of a cruise ship may transit a restricted area two if the passenger uses a passageway that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is demarcated for use by passengers in accordance with the marine facility security plan; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is supervised by a person who has a transportation security clearance.

Subsection.Text: A person who is being escorted in a restricted area shall remain with the escort while in the restricted area.
An escort shall remain with the person being escorted or ensure that another holder of a restricted area pass acts as the escort while the person is in the restricted area.
In the case of a restricted area two, no person shall escort more than 10 persons or one vehicle at one time.

Section.Text: No person shall provide access to or assist another person to enter a restricted area unless the person accessing the restricted area is authorized under section 380.

The holder of a restricted area pass shall, when they enter or remain in a restricted area, display the pass on their outer clothing and above their waist with, except in the case of a temporary restricted area pass, their photograph or other facial image visible at all times.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), a port administration or an operator of a marine facility may issue a restricted area pass or a key only to a person who requires access to a specific restricted area in the performance of their duties and, in the case of a restricted area two, who ordinarily works at the port or marine facility or who requires access to the restricted area on an occasional basis.
A port administration or an operator of a marine facility may only issue a temporary restricted area pass to a person who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a restricted area other than a restricted area two, is waiting for a restricted area pass that has been requested;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is a holder of a restricted area pass and is in one of the following circumstances:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: they have forgotten their restricted area pass, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: they have lost their restricted area pass or it was accidentally destroyed and they are waiting for a replacement restricted area pass for which they have made a request; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: does not ordinarily work at the port or marine facility and who, in the performance of their duties, requires temporary access to a restricted area other than a restricted area two.

Subsection.Text: Prior to issuing a restricted area pass, the port administration or operator of a marine facility shall confirm the identity of the person in the following manner:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a restricted area pass to be issued to a person who holds a transportation security clearance, by valid photo-bearing identification issued by

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the Government of Canada or the government of any province, territory or municipality in Canada, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: an employer known to the port administration or operator of the marine facility; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a restricted area pass to be issued to any other person, by

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: one of the means of identification referred to in paragraph (a), or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: other documentation containing sufficient information to enable identification of the person.

Subsection.Text: Prior to issuing a restricted area pass for a restricted area two, the port administration or operator of the marine facility shall verify with the Minister that the person has been issued a transportation security clearance as required by section 503.

The port administration or operator of the marine facility shall confirm the period during which access to the restricted area is required by way of documentation that sets out an expiry date or other relevant information.
The port administration or operator of the marine facility shall issue restricted area passes that comply with the requirements of sections 392 and 394, as applicable.
A holder of a restricted area pass or key that has been lost or stolen shall immediately report its loss or theft to the port administration or the operator of the marine facility.
The port administration or operator of the marine facility shall immediately cancel a restricted area pass and any associated key upon being notified of its loss or theft.
A port administration or an operator of a marine facility shall keep a record of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the number of restricted area passes or keys issued and, for each pass, the name of the holder, the number of the pass or key, the date of issue, the period of validity, and, if applicable, the date of suspension or revocation; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: lost or stolen passes or keys.

Subsection.Text: The port administration or operator of a marine facility shall ensure that the records referred to in subsection (1) are:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: kept for at least two years after the date they are made; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: available to the Minister on request.

Section.Text: A person shall not provide false information for the purpose of obtaining a restricted area pass or a key.
A person shall not use a restricted area pass or a key except while in the performance of their duties.

Subsection.Text: The holder of a restricted area pass or a key shall return it to the marine facility operator or the person who issued it when

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the holder ceases to work at a marine facility; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the holder otherwise ceases to require the restricted area pass or the key.

Subsection.Text: When a restricted area pass or a key is returned to an employer, the employer shall immediately give it to the marine facility operator or the person who issued it.

Section.Text: A person shall surrender on demand a restricted area pass or a key in their possession to the marine facility operator, the person who issued it, a peace officer or the Minister.
No person shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: loan or give a restricted area pass or a key that was issued to one person to another person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: alter or otherwise modify a restricted area pass or a key;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: have or use a restricted area pass or a key that was issued to another person;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: use a counterfeit restricted area pass or key; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: make or reproduce a copy of a restricted area pass or key.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), a restricted area pass shall show the name, height and eye colour of the person to whom the pass has been issued, a clear photograph of the person’s head and shoulders or other facial image and an expiry date that is not later than five years after the date of issue or, in the case of a restricted area pass issued to a person who holds a transportation security clearance, that is not later than the expiry date of the transportation security clearance.
A temporary restricted area pass need not meet the requirements of subsection (1), but it shall bear a mark that clearly distinguishes it as a temporary pass.

A port administration may issue keys and restricted area passes, and keep an up-to-date list, by name and position, of the holders of transportation security clearances, on behalf of marine facility operators in the port.

If a port administration administers restricted areas passes on behalf of marine facility operators in the port, a marine facility operator shall cooperate with the port administration and shall provide it with the information required.

Section.Text: Every restricted area pass issued to a holder of a transportation security clearance shall bear a mark that clearly distinguishes it from restricted area passes issued to persons who are not transportation security clearance holders.
